http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000100.definition: Presence of an unusually high number of lentigines (singular: lentigo), which are flat, tan to brown oval spots.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000100.label: Lymphedema
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000100.definition: Localized fluid retention and tissue swelling caused by a compromised lymphatic system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000100.label: Hirsutism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000100.definition: Abnormally increased hair growth referring to a male pattern of body hair (androgenic hair).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000100.label: Telangiectasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000100.definition: Telangiectasias refer to small dilated blood vessels located near the surface of the skin or mucous membranes, measuring between 0.5 and 1 millimeter in diameter. Telangiectasia are located especially on the tongue, lips, palate, fingers, face, conjunctiva, trunk, nail beds, and fingertips.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.label: Hypopigmentation of the skin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.definition: A reduction of skin color related to a decrease in melanin production and deposition.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.label: Multiple lipomas
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.definition: The presence of multiple lipomas (a type of benign tissue made of fatty tissue).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.label: Eruptive xanthomas
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.definition: Eruptive xanthomas are yellow-orange-to-red-brown papules that are often surrounded by an erythematous halo. They appear in crops on the buttocks, extensor surfaces of the extremities, and flexural creases. Acutely, variable amounts of pruritus and pain occur.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.label: Angiokeratoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.definition: Angiokeratomas are hyperkeratotic papules that are characterized histologically by superficial ectatic (i.e., dilated) blood vessels with epidermal proliferation. Clinically, angiokeratoma presents as a small, raised, dark-red spot.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.label: Prominent superficial veins
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.definition: A condition in which superficial veins (i.e., veins just under the skin) are more conspicuous or noticable than normal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.label: Anemic pallor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.definition: A type of pallor that is secondary to the presence of anemia.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.label: Abnormal palmar dermatoglyphics
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.definition: An abnormality of the dermatoglyphs, i.e., an abnormality of the patterns of ridges of the skin of palm of hand.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.label: Erythroderma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000101.definition: An inflammatory exfoliative dermatosis involving nearly all of the surface of the skin. Erythroderma develops suddenly. A patchy erythema may generalize and spread to affect most of the skin. Scaling may appear in 2-6 days and be accompanied by hot, red, dry skin, malaise, and fever.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.label: Albinism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.definition: An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of skin, hair and eye (iris and retina).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.label: Skin dimple over apex of long bone angulation
Urticaria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.definition: Raised, well-circumscribed areas of erythema and edema involving the dermis and epidermis. Urticaria is intensely pruritic, and blanches completely with pressure.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.label: Soft, doughy skin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.definition: A skin texture that is unusually soft (and may feel silky), and has a malleable consistency resembling that of dough.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.label: Hemangioma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.definition: A hemangioma is a benign tumor characterized by blood-filled spaces lined by benign endothelial cells. A hemangioma characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns) is called a cavernous hemangioma (in contrast to a hemangioma with small endothelial spaces, which is called capillary hemangioma).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.label: Poikiloderma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000102.definition: Poikiloderma refers to a patch of skin with (1) reticulated hypopigmentation and hyperpigmentation, (2) wrinkling secondary to epidermal atrophy, and (3) telangiectasias.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000103.label: Fragile skin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000103.definition: Skin that splits easily with minimal injury.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000103.label: Absent distal interphalangeal creases
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000103.definition: Absence of the distal interphalangeal flexion creases of the fingers.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000103.label: Hypermelanotic macule
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000103.definition: A hyperpigmented circumscribed area of change in normal skin color without elevation or depression of any size.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000103.label: Parakeratosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000103.definition: Abnormal formation of the keratinocytes of the epidermis characterized by persistence of nuclei, incomplete formation of keratin, and moistness and swelling of the keratinocytes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.label: Facial erythema
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.definition: Redness of the skin of the face, caused by hyperemia of the capillaries in the lower layers of the skin.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.label: Intermittent jaundice
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.definition: Jaundice that is sometimes present, sometimes not.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.label: Atopic dermatitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.definition: Atopic dermatitis (AD) or atopic eczema is an itchy, inflammatory skin condition with a predilection for the skin flexures. It is characterized by poorly defined erythema with edema, vesicles, and weeping in the acute stage and skin thickening (lichenification) in the chronic stage.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.label: Cavernous hemangioma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.definition: The presence of a cavernous hemangioma. A hemangioma characterized by large endothelial spaces (caverns) is called a cavernous hemangioma.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000104.label: Absent dorsal skin creases over affected joints

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.label: Seborrheic dermatitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.definition: Seborrheic dermatitis is a form of eczema which is closely related to dandruff. It causes dry or greasy peeling of the scalp, eyebrows, and face, and sometimes trunk.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.label: Nevus flammeus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.definition: A congenital vascular malformation consisting of superficial and deep dilated capillaries in the skin which produce a reddish to purplish discolouration of the skin.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.label: Erysipelas
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.definition: Increased susceptibility to erysipelas, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of erysipelas, which is a superficial infection of the skin, typically involving the lymphatic system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.label: Milia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.definition: Presence of multiple small cysts containing keratin (skin protein) and presenting as tiny pearly-white bumps just under the surface of the skin.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.label: Aplasia cutis congenita
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.definition: A developmental defect resulting in the congenital absence of skin in multiple or solitary non-inflammatory, well-demarcated, oval or circular ulcers with a diameter of about 1 to 2 cm. Aplasia cutis congenita most commonly occurs on the scalp, but may present in the face, trunk, or limbs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.label: Poor wound healing
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.definition: A reduced ability to heal cutaneous wounds.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.label: Pterygium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000105.definition: Pterygia are 'winglike' triangular membranes occurring in the neck, eyes, knees, elbows, ankles or digits.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.label: Axillary pterygium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.definition: Presence of a cutaneous membrane (flap) in the armpit.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.label: Acne
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.definition: A skin condition in which there is an increase in sebum secretion by the pilosebaceous apparatus associated with open comedones (blackheads), closed comedones (whiteheads), and pustular nodules (papules, pustules, and cysts).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.label: Atypical nevus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.definition: A large pigmented lesion measuring 5-15 mm in diameter with irregular, notched, and ill defined border and with color that may range from tan to dark brown to pink.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.label: Acrocyanosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.definition: Bluish discoloration of the skin of the hands or feet.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.label: Striae distensae
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.definition: Thinned, erythematous, depressed bands of atrophic skin. Initially, striae appear as flattened and thinned, pinkish linear regions of the skin. Striae tend to enlarge in length and become reddish or purplish. Later, striae tend to appear as white, depressed bands that are parallel to the lines of skin tension. Striae distensae occur most often in areas that have been subject to distension such as the lower back, buttocks, thighs, breast, abdomen, and shoulders.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.label: Neurofibroma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.definition: A benign peripheral nerve sheath tumor that generally appears as a soft, skin-colored papule or small subcutaneous nodule. Individuals with neurofibromatosis can have numerous neurofibromas.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.label: Episodic hyperhidrosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000106.definition: Intermittent episodes of abnormally increased perspiration.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000107.label: Angiokeratoma corporis diffusum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000107.definition: Angiokeratoma corporis diffusum (ACD) is typically characterized by innumerable small red to black papules which occur in clusters and are situated symmetrically in the bathing trunks area. The number of lesions and the extension of the body increase steadily with time so that generalization and mucosal involvement are common. The single lesion begins with a minute reddish papule which enlarges to up to 10 mm in diameter, becomes dark red to black with a discrete keratotic overgrowth. Histologically, the papules are characterized by superficial dilated capillaries in papillary dermis with epidermal proliferation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000107.label: Atypical nevi in non-sun exposed areas
Atrophic scars
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000107.definition: Scars that form a depression compared to the level of the surrounding skin because of damage to the collagen, fat or other tissues below the skin.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.label: Biliary tract abnormality
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.definition: An abnormality of the biliary tree.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.label: Cholelithiasis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.definition: Hard, pebble-like deposits that form within the gallbladder.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.label: Cholecystitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.definition: The presence of inflammatory changes in the gallbladder.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.label: Ectopia lentis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.definition: Dislocation or malposition of the crystalline lens of the eye. A partial displacement (or dislocation) of the lens is described as a subluxation of the lens, while a complete displacement is termed luxation of the lens. A complete displacement occurs if the lens is completely outside the patellar fossa of the lens, either in the anterior chamber, in the vitreous, or directly on the retina. If the lens is partially displaced but still contained within the lens space, then it is termed subluxation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.label: Corneal arcus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.definition: A hazy, grayish-white ring about 2 mm in width located close to but separated from the limbus (the corneoscleral junction). Corneal arcus generally occurs bilaterally, and is related to lipid deposition in the cornea. Corneal arcus can occur in elderly persons as a part of the aging process but may be associated with hypercholesterolemia in people under the age of 50 years.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.label: Papilledema
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.definition: Papilledema refers to edema (swelling) of the optic disc secondary to any factor which increases cerebral spinal fluid pressure.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.label: Developmental glaucoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.definition: Glaucoma which forms during the early years of a child's life is called developmental or congenital glaucoma.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.label: Brushfield spots
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000108.definition: The presence of whitish spots in a ring-like arrangement at the periphery of the iris.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.label: Abnormally large globe
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.definition: Diffusely large eye (with megalocornea) without glaucoma.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.label: Absent lacrimal punctum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.definition: No identifiable superior and/or inferior lacrimal punctum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.label: Optic nerve dysplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.definition: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the optic nerve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.label: Iridocyclitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.definition: A type of anterior uveitis, in which there is Inflammation of the iris and the ciliary body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.label: Keratoconjunctivitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.definition: Inflammation of the cornea and conjunctiva.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.label: Keratoconjunctivitis sicca
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.definition: Dryness of the eye related to deficiency of the tear film components (aqueous, mucin, or lipid), lid surface abnormalities, or epithelial abnormalities. Keratoconjunctivitis sicca often results in a scratchy or sandy sensation (foreign body sensation) in the eyes, and may also be associated with itching, inability to produce tears, photosensitivity, redness, pain, and difficulty in moving the eyelids.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.label: Abnormal fundus morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000109.definition: Any structural abnormality of the fundus of the eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.label: Heterochromia iridis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.definition: Heterochromia iridis is a difference in the color of the iris in the two eyes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.label: Angioid streaks of the fundus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.definition: Irregular lines in the deep retina that are typically configured in a radiating fashion and emanate from the optic disc. Angioid streaks are crack-like dehiscences in abnormally thickened and calcified Bruch's membrane, resulting in atrophy of the overlying retinal pigment epithelium. They may be associated with a number of endocrine, metabolic, and connective tissue abnormalities but are frequently idiopathic.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.label: Abnormal macular morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.definition: A structural abnormality of the macula lutea, which is an oval-shaped highly pigmented yellow spot near the center of the retina.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.label: Retinal atrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.definition: Well-demarcated area(s) of partial or complete depigmentation in the fundus, reflecting atrophy of the retinal pigment epithelium with associated retinal photoreceptor loss.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.label: Periorbital hyperpigmentation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.definition: Increased pigmentation of the skin in the region surrounding the orbit of the eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.label: Ocular albinism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000110.definition: An abnormal reduction in the amount of pigmentation (reduced or absent) of the iris and retina.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.label: Leber optic atrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.definition: Degeneration of retinal ganglion cells and their axons.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.label: Xanthelasma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.definition: The presence of xanthomata in the skin of the eyelid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.label: Posterior polar cataract
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.definition: A polar cataract that affects the posterior pole of the lens.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.label: Macular coloboma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.definition: A congenital defect of the macula distinct from coloboma associated with optic fissure closure defects. Macular coloboma is characterized by a sharply defined, rather large defect in the central area of the fundus that is oval or round, and coarsely pigmented.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.label: Sudden loss of visual acuity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.definition: Severe loss of visual acuity within hours or days. This is characteristic of Leber hereditary optic neuropathy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.label: Juvenile cataract
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.definition: A type of cataract that is not apparent at birth but that arises in childhood or adolescence.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.label: Keratoglobus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000111.definition: Limbus-to-limbus corneal thinning, often greatest in the periphery, with globular protrusion of the cornea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000112.label: Abnormality of corneal size
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000112.definition: Any abnormality of the size or morphology of the cornea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000112.label: Transient unilateral blurring of vision
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000112.definition: Transient blurring of vision associated with the aura phase of migraine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000112.label: Cryptophthalmos
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000112.definition: Cryptophthalmos is a condition of total absence of eyelids and the skin of forehead is continuous with that of cheek, in which the eyeball is completely concealed by the skin, which is stretched over the orbital cavity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000112.label: Trichiasis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000112.definition: Inversion and rubbing of the eyelashes against the globe of the eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.label: Corneal dystrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.definition: The term corneal dystrophy embraces a heterogenous group of bilateral genetically determined non-inflammatory corneal diseases that are restricted to the cornea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.label: Lens subluxation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.definition: Partial dislocation of the lens of the eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.label: Constriction of peripheral visual field
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.definition: An absolute or relative decrease in retinal sensitivity extending from edge (periphery) of the visual field in a concentric pattern. The visual field is the area that is perceived simultaneously by a fixating eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.label: Anterior polar cataract
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.definition: A polar cataract that affects the anterior pole of the lens.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.label: Retinal arteriolar tortuosity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.definition: The presence of an increased number of twists and turns of the retinal arterioles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.label: Alternating esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000113.definition: Esotropia in which either eye may be used for fixation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.label: Limbal dermoid
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.definition: A benign tumor typically found at the junction of the cornea and sclera (limbal epibullar dermoid).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.label: Severely reduced visual acuity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.definition: Severe reduction of the ability to see defined as visual acuity less than 6/60 (20/200 in US notation; 0.1 in decimal notation) but at least 3/60 (20/400 in US notation; 0.05 in decimal notation).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.label: Lenticonus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.definition: A conical projection of the anterior or posterior surface of the lens, occurring as a developmental anomaly.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.label: Orbital cyst
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.definition: Presence of a cyst in the region of the periorbital tissues. Orbital cysts can be derived from epithelial or glandular tissue within or surrounding the orbit (lacrimal glands, salivary glands, conjunctival, oral, nasal, or sinus epithelium).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.label: Retinal exudate
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.definition: Fluid which has escaped from retinal blood vessels with a high concentration of lipid, protein, and cellular debris with a typically bright, reflective, white or cream colored appearance on the surface of the retina.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.label: Lattice corneal dystrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000114.definition: The presence of fine, branching linear opacities in Bowman's layer in the central area that may spread to the periphery in the clinical course. The deep corneal stroma may be involved but the process does not reach Descemet's membrane. Recurrent corneal erosion may occur. Histologic examination reveals amyloid deposits in the collagen fibers of the cornea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.label: Impaired horizontal smooth pursuit
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.definition: An abnormality of ocular smooth pursuit characterized by an impairment of the ability to track horizontally moving objects.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.label: Saccadic smooth pursuit
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.definition: An abnormality of tracking eye movements in which smooth pursuit is interrupted by an abnormally high number of saccadic movements.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.label: Septate vagina
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.definition: The presence of a vaginal septum, thereby creating a vaginal duplication. The septum is longitudinal in the majority of cases.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.label: Abnormality of the hand
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.definition: An abnormality affecting one or both hands.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.label: Brachydactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.definition: Digits that appear disproportionately short compared to the hand/foot. The word brachydactyly is used here to describe a series distinct patterns of shortened digits (brachydactyly types A-E). This is the sense used here.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.label: Syndactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000115.definition: Webbing or fusion of the fingers or toes, involving soft parts only or including bone structure. Bony fusions are referred to as "bony" syndactyly if the fusion occurs in a radio-ulnar axis. Fusions of bones of the fingers or toes in a proximo-distal axis are referred to as "symphalangism".

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000116.label: Hand polydactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000116.definition: A kind of polydactyly characterized by the presence of a supernumerary finger or fingers.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000116.label: Postaxial hand polydactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000116.definition: Supernumerary digits located at the ulnar side of the hand (that is, on the side with the fifth finger).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000116.label: Arachnodactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000116.definition: Abnormally long and slender fingers ("spider fingers").

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000116.label: Broad palm
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000116.definition: For children from birth to 4 years of age the palm width is more than 2 SD above the mean; for children from 4 to 16 years of age the palm width is above the 95th centile; or, the width of the palm appears disproportionately wide for the length.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000117.label: Split hand
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000117.definition: A condition in which middle parts of the hand (fingers and metacarpals) are missing giving a cleft appearance. The severity is very variable ranging from slightly hypoplastic middle fingers over absent middel fingers as far as oligo- or monodactyl hands.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000117.label: Abnormal thumb morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000117.definition: An abnormal structure of the first digit of the hand.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000117.label: Preaxial hand polydactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000117.definition: Supernumerary digits located at the radial side of the hand. Polydactyly (supernumerary digits) involving the thumb occurs in many distinct forms of high variability and severity. Ranging from fleshy nubbins over varying degrees of partial duplication/splitting to completely duplicated or even triplicated thumbs or preaxial (on the radial side of the hand) supernumerary digits.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000117.label: Ulnar claw
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000117.definition: An abnormal hand position characterized by hyperextension of the fourth and fifth fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints and flexion of the interphalangeal joints of the same fingers such that they are curled towards the palm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.label: Hand oligodactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.definition: A developmental defect resulting in the presence of fewer than the normal number of fingers.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.label: Adducted thumb
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.definition: In the resting position, the tip of the thumb is on, or near, the palm, close to the base of the fourth or fifth finger.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.label: Tapered finger
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.definition: The gradual reduction in girth of the finger from proximal to distal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.label: Hyperextensibility of the finger joints
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.definition: The ability of the finger joints to move beyond their normal range of motion.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.label: Hand clenching
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000118.definition: An abnormal hand posture in which the hands are clenched to fists. All digits held completely flexed at the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints. In prenatal sonography of the fetal clenched hand, the index finger overlaps a clenched fist formed by the other digits. The proximal interphalangeal articulation of the index finger is flexed and ulnarly deviated, and the thumb is adducted.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.label: Abnormal carpal morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.definition: An abnormality affecting the carpal bones of the wrist (scaphoid, lunate, triquetral, pisiform, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, hamate).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.label: Ulnar deviation of the hand or of fingers of the hand
Abnormalities of placenta or umbilical cord
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.definition: An abnormality of the placenta (the organ that connects the developing fetus to the uterine wall) or of the umbilical cord (the cord that connects the fetus to the placenta).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.label: Single umbilical artery
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.definition: Single umbilical artery (SUA) is the absence of one of the two umbilical arteries surrounding the fetal bladder and in the fetal umbilical cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.label: Short umbilical cord
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.definition: Decreased length of the umbilical cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.label: Abnormality of prenatal development or birth
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.definition: An abnormality of the fetus or the birth of the fetus, excluding structural abnormalities.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.label: Triphalangeal thumb
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000119.definition: A thumb with three phalanges in a single, proximo-distal axis. Thus, this term applies if the thumb has an accessory phalanx, leading to a digit like appearance of the thumb.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000120.label: Distal symphalangism of hands
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000120.definition: The term distal symphalangism refers to a bony fusion of the distal and middle phalanges of the digits of the hand, in other words the distal interphalangeal joint (DIJ) is missing which can be seen either on x-rays or as an absence of the distal interphalangeal finger creases.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.label: Abnormal fingertip morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.definition: An abnormal structure of the tip (end) of a finger.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.label: Prominent fingertip pads
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.definition: A soft tissue prominence of the ventral aspects of the fingertips. The term "persistent fetal fingertip pads" is often used as a synonym, but should better not be used because it implies knowledge of history of the patient which often does not exist.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.label: Camptodactyly of 2nd-5th fingers
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.definition: The distal interphalangeal joint and/or the proximal interphalangeal joint of the second to fifth fingers cannot be extended to 180 degrees by either active or passive extension.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.label: Delayed ossification of carpal bones
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.definition: Ossification of carpal bones occurs later than age-adjusted norms.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.label: Clubbing
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.definition: Broadening of the soft tissues (non-edematous swelling of soft tissues) of the digital tips in all dimensions associated with an increased longitudinal and lateral curvature of the nails.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.label: Autoamputation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000121.definition: Auto-amputation is the spontaneous detachment of an appendage from the body due to long standing pathology.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000122.label: Interphalangeal joint contracture of finger
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000122.definition: Chronic loss of joint motion in an interphalangeal joint of a finger due to structural changes in non-bony tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000122.label: Pointed proximal second through fifth metacarpals
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000122.definition: All of the metacarpal bones of the hand have a pointed proximal appearance.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000122.label: obsolete Acral ulceration and osteomyelitis leading to autoamputation of digits
Abnormality of the thenar eminence
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000122.definition: An abnormality of the thenar eminence, i.e., of the muscle on the palm of the human hand just beneath the thumb.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.label: Nail bed telangiectasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.definition: Telangiectases in the area of the nails.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.label: 2-3 finger syndactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.definition: Syndactyly with fusion of fingers two and three.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.label: Hitchhiker thumb
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.definition: With the hand relaxed and the thumb in the plane of the palm, the axis of the thumb forms an angle of at least 90 degrees with the long axis of the hand.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.label: Slender finger
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.definition: Fingers that are disproportionately narrow (reduced girth) for the hand/foot size or build of the individual.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.label: Wrist flexion contracture
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000123.definition: A chronic loss of wrist joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevent normal movement of the joints of the wrist.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000124.label: Small thenar eminence
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000124.definition: Underdevelopment of the thenar eminence with reduced palmar soft tissue mass surrounding the base of the thumb.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000124.label: Short tubular bones of the hand
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000124.definition: Decreased length of the tubular bones of the hand, that is, the phalanges and metacarpals.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000124.label: Intellectual disability
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000124.definition: Intellectual disability, previously referred to as mental retardation, is characterized by subnormal intellectual functioning that occurs during the developmental period. It is defined by an IQ score below 70.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.label: Seizure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.definition: A seizure is an intermittent abnormality of nervous system physiology characterised by a transient occurrence of signs and/or symptoms due to abnormal excessive or synchronous neuronal activity in the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.label: Ataxia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.definition: Cerebellar ataxia refers to ataxia due to dysfunction of the cerebellum. This causes a variety of elementary neurological deficits including asynergy (lack of coordination between muscles, limbs and joints), dysmetria (lack of ability to judge distances that can lead to under- or overshoot in grasping movements), and dysdiadochokinesia (inability to perform rapid movements requiring antagonizing muscle groups to be switched on and off repeatedly).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.label: Hypotonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.definition: Hypotonia is an abnormally low muscle tone (the amount of tension or resistance to movement in a muscle). Even when relaxed, muscles have a continuous and passive partial contraction which provides some resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia thus manifests as diminished resistance to passive stretching. Hypotonia is not the same as muscle weakness, although the two conditions can co-exist.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.label: Lethargy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.definition: A state of disinterest, listlessness, and indifference, resulting in difficulty performing simple tasks or concentrating.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.label: Intellectual disability, mild
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.definition: Mild intellectual disability is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 50-69.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.label: Spasticity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.definition: A motor disorder characterized by a velocity-dependent increase in tonic stretch reflexes with increased muscle tone, exaggerated (hyperexcitable) tendon reflexes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.label: Spastic paraplegia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.definition: Spasticity and weakness of the leg and hip muscles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.label: Coma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000125.definition: The complete absence of wakefulness and consciousness, which is evident through a lack of response to any form of external stimuli.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.label: Dysarthria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.definition: Dysarthric speech is a general description referring to a neurological speech disorder characterized by poor articulation. Depending on the involved neurological structures, dysarthria may be further classified as spastic, flaccid, ataxic, hyperkinetic and hypokinetic, or mixed.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.label: Excessive daytime somnolence
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.definition: A state of abnormally strong desire for sleep during the daytime.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.label: Global developmental delay
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.definition: A delay in the achievement of motor or mental milestones in the domains of development of a child, including motor skills, speech and language, cognitive skills, and social and emotional skills. This term should only be used to describe children younger than five years of age.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.label: Spastic diplegia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.definition: Spasticity (neuromuscular hypertonia) primarily in the muscles of the legs, hips, and pelvis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.label: Hyporeflexia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.definition: Reduction of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.label: Choreoathetosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.definition: Involuntary movements characterized by both athetosis (inability to sustain muscles in a fixed position) and chorea (widespread jerky arrhythmic movements).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.label: Mental deterioration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.definition: Loss of previously present mental abilities, generally in adults.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.label: Hemiparesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000126.definition: Loss of strength in the arm, leg, and sometimes face on one side of the body. Hemiplegia refers to a complete loss of strength, whereas hemiparesis refers to an incomplete loss of strength.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.label: Motor delay
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.definition: A type of Developmental delay characterized by a delay in acquiring motor skills.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.label: Polyneuropathy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.definition: A generalized disorder of peripheral nerves.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.label: Cerebellar atrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.definition: Cerebellar atrophy is defined as a cerebellum with initially normal structures, in a posterior fossa with normal size, which displays enlarged fissures (interfolial spaces) in comparison to the foliae secondary to loss of tissue. Cerebellar atrophy implies irreversible loss of tissue and result from an ongoing progressive disease until a final stage is reached or a single injury, e.g. an intoxication or infectious event.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.label: Agenesis of corpus callosum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.definition: Absence of the corpus callosum as a result of the failure of the corpus callosum to develop, which can be the result of a failure in any one of the multiple steps of callosal development including cellular proliferation and migration, axonal growth or glial patterning at the midline.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.label: Hypertonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.definition: A condition in which there is increased muscle tone so that arms or legs, for example, are stiff and difficult to move.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.label: Orthostatic hypotension
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.definition: A form of hypotension characterized by a sudden fall in blood pressure that occurs when a person assumes a standing position.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.label: Syncope
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000127.definition: Syncope refers to a generalized weakness of muscles with loss of postural tone, inability to stand upright, and loss of consciousness. Once the patient is in a horizontal position, blood flow to the brain is no longer hindered by gravitation and consciousness is regained. Unconsciousness usually lasts for seconds to minutes. Headache and drowsiness (which usually follow seizures) do not follow a syncopal attack. Syncope results from a sudden impairment of brain metabolism usually due to a reduction in cerebral blood flow.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.label: Tetany
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.definition: A condition characterized by intermittent involuntary contraction of muscles (spasms) related to hypocalcemia or occasionally magnesium deficiency.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.label: Bulbar palsy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.definition: Bulbar weakness (or bulbar palsy) refers to bilateral impairment of function of the lower cranial nerves IX, X, XI and XII, which occurs due to lower motor neuron lesion either at nuclear or fascicular level in the medulla or from bilateral lesions of the lower cranial nerves outside the brain-stem. Bulbar weakness is often associated with difficulty in chewing, weakness of the facial muscles, dysarthria, palatal weakness and regurgitation of fluids, dysphagia, and dysphonia.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.label: Areflexia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.definition: Absence of neurologic reflexes such as the knee-jerk reaction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.label: Spastic tetraparesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.definition: Spastic weakness affecting all four limbs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.label: Gait disturbance
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.definition: The term gait disturbance can refer to any disruption of the ability to walk. In general, this can refer to neurological diseases but also fractures or other sources of pain that is triggered upon walking. However, in the current context gait disturbance refers to difficulty walking on the basis of a neurological or muscular disease.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.label: Confusion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000128.definition: Lack of clarity and coherence of thought, perception, understanding, or action.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000129.label: Generalized hypotonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000129.definition: Generalized muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000129.label: Abnormal cranial nerve morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000129.definition: Structural abnormality affecting one or more of the cranial nerves, which emerge directly from the brain stem.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000129.label: Stroke
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000129.definition: Sudden impairment of blood flow to a part of the brain due to occlusion or rupture of an artery to the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000129.label: Encephalopathy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000129.definition: Encephalopathy is a term that means brain disease, damage, or malfunction. In general, encephalopathy is manifested by an altered mental state.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.label: Parkinsonism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.definition: Characteristic neurologic anomaly resulting from degeneration of dopamine-generating cells in the substantia nigra, a region of the midbrain, characterized clinically by shaking, rigidity, slowness of movement and difficulty with walking and gait.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.label: Pachygyria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.definition: Pachygyria is a malformation of cortical development with abnormally wide gyri with sulci 1,5-3 cm apart and abnormally thick cortex measuring more than 5 mm (radiological definition). See also neuropathological definitions for 2-, 3-, and 4-layered lissencephaly.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.label: Torsion dystonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.definition: Sustained involuntary muscle contractions that produce twisting and repetitive movements of the body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.label: Dandy-Walker malformation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.definition: A congenital brain malformation typically characterized by incomplete formation of the cerebellar vermis, dilation of the fourth ventricle, and enlargement of the posterior fossa. In layman's terms, Dandy Walker malformation is a cyst in the cerebellum (typically symmetrical) that is involved with the fourth ventricle. This may interfere with the ability to drain cerebrospinal fluid from the brain, resulting in hydrocephalus. Dandy Walker cysts are formed during early embryonic development, while the brain forms. The cyst in the cerebellum typically has several blood vessels running through it connecting to the brain, thereby prohibiting surgical removal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.label: Tongue fasciculations
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000130.definition: Fasciculations or fibrillation affecting the tongue muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.label: Dysmetria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.definition: A type of ataxia characterized by the inability to carry out movements with the correct range and motion across the plane of more than one joint related to incorrect estimation of the distances required for targeted movements.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.label: Abnormal nervous system electrophysiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.definition: An abnormality of the function of the electrical signals with which nerve cells communicate with each other or with muscles as measured by electrophysiological investigations.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.label: Giant somatosensory evoked potentials
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.definition: An abnormal enlargement (i.e. increase in measured voltage) of somatosensory evoked potentials.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.label: Reduced tendon reflexes
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.definition: Diminution of tendon reflexes, which is an invariable sign of peripheral nerve disease.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.label: Abnormal cerebellum morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.definition: Any structural abnormality of the cerebellum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.label: Neonatal hypotonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000131.definition: Muscular hypotonia (abnormally low muscle tone) manifesting in the neonatal period.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.label: Cerebellar vermis hypoplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.definition: Underdevelopment of the vermis of cerebellum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.label: Cerebellar hypoplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.definition: Cerebellar hypoplasia is a descriptive term implying a cerebellum with a reduced volume, but a normal shape and is stable over time.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.label: Hypoglycemic coma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.definition: Coma induced by low blood sugar.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.label: EEG with irregular generalized spike and wave complexes
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.definition: EEG shows spikes (<80 ms) and waves, which are recorded over the entire scalp and do not have a specific frequency.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.label: Photosensitive myoclonic seizure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.definition: Generalised myoclonic seizure provoked by flashing or flickering light.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.label: Specific learning disability
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000132.definition: Impairment of certain skills such as reading or writing, coordination, self-control, or attention that interfere with the ability to learn. The impairment is not related to a global deficiency of intelligence.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.label: Absent septum pellucidum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.definition: Absence of the septum pellucidum (meaning translucent wall in Latin - SP), also known as the ventricle of Sylvius. The septum pellucidum is a thin, triangular double membrane separating the frontal horns of the right and left lateral ventricles of the brain. It extends between the anterior portion of the corpus callosum, and the body of the fornix and its width varies from 1.5 to 3.0 mm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.label: Dystonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.definition: An abnormally increased muscular tone that causes fixed abnormal postures. There is a slow, intermittent twisting motion that leads to exaggerated turning and posture of the extremities and trunk.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.label: Communicating hydrocephalus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.definition: A form of hydrocephalus in which there is no visible obstruction to the flow of the cerebrospinal fluid between the ventricles and subarachnoid space.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.label: Bimanual synkinesia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.definition: Involuntary movements of one hand that accompany and mirror intentional movements of the opposite hand.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.label: Myoclonus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.definition: Very brief, involuntary random muscular contractions occurring at rest, in response to sensory stimuli, or accompanying voluntary movements.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.label: Tremor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.definition: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement about a joint axis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.label: Partial agenesis of the corpus callosum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.definition: A partial failure of the development of the corpus callosum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.label: Lissencephaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000133.definition: A spectrum of malformations of cortical development caused by insufficient neuronal migration that subsumes the terms agyria, pachygyria and subcortical band heterotopia. See also neuropathological definitions for 2-, 3-, and 4-layered lissencephaly.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.label: Enhancement of the C-reflex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.definition: Increase in amplitude of a long-loop response upon somatosensory evoked potential testing, representing an electrically evoked myoclonic response.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.label: Cerebral hemorrhage
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.definition: Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.label: Kernicterus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.definition: Damage to cerebral nuclei caused in infants by highly increased levels of unconjugated bilirubin. The basal ganglia and brainstem nuclei could be shown to have a yellow staining historically in infants who died of kernicterus, that is, kernicterus is strictly speaking a pathological diagnosis. The presence of kernicterus may be inferred in infants with characteristic acute or chronic bilirubin-induced neurological dysfunction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.label: Absent speech
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.definition: Complete lack of development of speech and language abilities.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.label: Psychotic mentation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.definition: A pattern of thinking and perceiving characterized by a loss of contact with reality, leading to significant changes in thoughts, perceptions, and behaviors.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.label: Hyperreflexia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.definition: Hyperreflexia is the presence of hyperactive stretch reflexes of the muscles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.label: Brisk reflexes
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.definition: Tendon reflexes that are noticeably more active than usual (conventionally denoted 3+ on clinical examination). Brisk reflexes may or may not indicate a neurological lesion. They are distinguished from hyperreflexia by the fact that hyerreflexia is characterized by hyperactive repeating (clonic) reflexes, which are considered to be always abnormal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.label: Facial diplegia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000134.definition: Facial diplegia refers to bilateral facial palsy (bilateral facial palsy is much rarer than unilateral facial palsy).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000135.label: Slurred speech
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000135.definition: Abnormal coordination of muscles involved in speech.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000135.label: Jerk-locked premyoclonus spikes
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000135.definition: Jerk-locked averaging (JLA) is used to record the timing and distribution of brain activity preceding brisk involuntary movements such as those observed in patients with myoclonus. JLA is capable of revealing a premyoclonus spike in the absence of paroxysmal activity in the routine EEG.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000135.label: Megalencephaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000135.definition: Diffuse enlargement of the entire cerebral hemispheres leading to macrocephaly (with or without overlying cortical dysplasia).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000135.label: Plagiocephaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000135.definition: Asymmetric head shape, which is usually a combination of unilateral occipital flattening with ipsilateral frontal prominence, leading to rhomboid cranial shape.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.label: Holoprosencephaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.definition: Holoprosencephaly is a structural anomaly of the brain in which the developing forebrain fails to divide into two separate hemispheres and ventricles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.label: Nystagmus-induced head nodding
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.definition: Head movements associated with nystagmus, that may represent an attempt to compensate for the involuntary eye movements and to improve vision.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.label: Calvarial skull defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.definition: A localized defect in the bone of the skull resulting from abnormal embryological development. The defect is covered by normal skin. In some cases, skull x-rays have shown underlying lytic bone lesions which have closed before the age of one year.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.label: Craniosynostosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.definition: Craniosynostosis refers to the premature closure of the cranial sutures. Primary craniosynostosis refers to the closure of one or more sutures due to abnormalities in skull development, and secondary craniosynostosis results from failure of brain growth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.label: Abnormal joint morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000136.definition: An abnormal structure or form of the joints, i.e., one or more of the articulations where two bones join.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000137.label: Rheumatoid arthritis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000137.definition: Inflammatory changes in the synovial membranes and articular structures with widespread fibrinoid degeneration of the collagen fibers in mesenchymal tissues, as well as atrophy and rarefaction of bony structures.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000137.label: Flexion contracture
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000137.definition: A flexion contracture is a bent (flexed) joint that cannot be straightened actively or passively. It is thus a chronic loss of joint motion due to structural changes in muscle, tendons, ligaments, or skin that prevents normal movement of joints.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000137.label: Limitation of joint mobility
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000137.definition: A reduction in the freedom of movement of one or more joints.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000137.label: Limited elbow extension
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000137.definition: Limited ability to straighten the arm at the elbow joint.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.label: Joint hypermobility
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.definition: The ability of a joint to move beyond its normal range of motion.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.label: Abnormal hip joint morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.definition: An abnormality of the hip joint.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.label: Hip dysplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.definition: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the hip.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.label: Joint stiffness
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.definition: Joint stiffness is a perceived sensation of tightness in a joint or joints when attempting to move them after a period of inactivity. Joint stiffness typically subsides over time.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.label: Joint laxity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000138.definition: Lack of stability of a joint.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000139.label: Cirrhosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000139.definition: A chronic disorder of the liver in which liver tissue becomes scarred and is partially replaced by regenerative nodules and fibrotic tissue resulting in loss of liver function.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000139.label: Hepatic fibrosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000139.definition: The presence of excessive fibrous connective tissue in the liver. Fibrosis is a reparative or reactive process.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000139.label: Cholestasis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000139.definition: Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in bile ducts.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000139.label: Hepatic steatosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000139.definition: Steatosis is a term used to denote lipid accumulation within hepatocytes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.label: obsolete Hepatic abscesses due to immunodeficiency
Hepatocellular carcinoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.definition: A kind of neoplasm of the liver that originates in hepatocytes and presents macroscopically as a soft and hemorrhagic tan mass in the liver.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.label: Macrovesicular hepatic steatosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.definition: A form of hepatic steatosis characterized by the presence of large, lipid-laden vesicles in the affected hepatocytes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.label: Periportal fibrosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.definition: The presence of fibrosis affecting the interlobular stroma of liver.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.label: Intrahepatic cholestasis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.definition: Impairment of bile flow due to obstruction in the small bile ducts within the liver.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.label: Bile duct proliferation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.definition: Proliferative changes of the bile ducts.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.label: Portal hypertension
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000140.definition: Increased pressure in the portal vein.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.label: Decreased liver function
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.definition: Reduced ability of the liver to perform its functions.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.label: Enteroviral hepatitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.definition: Inflammation of the liver due to infection with enterovirus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.label: Micronodular cirrhosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.definition: A type of cirrhosis characterized by the presence of small regenerative nodules.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.label: Microvesicular hepatic steatosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.definition: A form of hepatic steatosis characterized by the presence of small, lipid-laden vesicles in the affected hepatocytes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.label: X-linked inheritance
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.definition: A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the X chromosome.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.label: X-linked recessive inheritance
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000141.definition: A mode of inheritance that is observed for recessive traits related to a gene encoded on the X chromosome. In the context of medical genetics, X-linked recessive disorders manifest in males (who have one copy of the X chromosome and are thus hemizygotes), but generally not in female heterozygotes who have one mutant and one normal allele.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000142.label: Abnormality of the musculature of the hand
X-linked dominant inheritance
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000142.definition: A mode of inheritance that is observed for dominant traits related to a gene encoded on the X chromosome. In the context of medical genetics, X-linked dominant disorders tend to manifest very severely in affected males. The severity of manifestation in females may depend on the degree of skewed X inactivation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000142.label: Non-Mendelian inheritance
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000142.definition: A mode of inheritance that depends on genetic determinants in more than one gene.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000142.label: Mitochondrial inheritance
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000142.definition: A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the mitochondrial genome. Because the mitochondrial genome is essentially always maternally inherited, a mitochondrial condition can only be transmitted by females, although the condition can affect both sexes. The proportion of mutant mitochondria can vary (heteroplasmy).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000143.label: Hepatosplenomegaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000143.definition: Simultaneous enlargement of the liver and spleen.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000143.label: Abnormality of the shoulder girdle musculature
Abnormality of the foot musculature
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000143.definition: An anomaly of the musculature of foot.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000143.label: Abnormality of the musculature of the lower limbs
Abnormal abdomen morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000143.definition: A structural abnormality of the abdomen ('belly'), that is, the part of the body between the pelvis and the thorax.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000144.label: Abnormality of the musculature of the thigh
Typified by somatic mosaicism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000144.definition: Description of conditions in which affected individuals typically display somatic mosaicism, i.e., genetically distinct populations of somatic cells in a given organism caused by DNA mutations, epigenetic alterations of DNA, chromosomal abnormalities or the spontaneous reversion of inherited mutations. In many conditions typified by somatic mosaicism, constitutive mutation is lethal and cases are exclusively or predominantly mosaic.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000144.label: obsolete Autosomal dominant somatic cell mutation
Abnormality of the musculature of the upper limbs

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000145.label: Y-linked inheritance
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000145.definition: A mode of inheritance that is observed for traits related to a gene encoded on the Y chromosome.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000145.label: obsolete Autosomal dominant contiguous gene syndrome
Abnormality of the musculature of the upper arm
1-3 toe syndactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000145.definition: Syndactyly with fusion of toes one to three.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.label: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the skeletal musculature
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the musculature.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.label: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the shoulder musculature
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the muscles of the shoulder.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.label: Contiguous gene syndrome
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.definition: A syndrome caused by the effects of abnormality (typically a deletion or duplication) of 2 or more adjacent genes

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.label: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the musculature of the upper limbs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the musculature of the upper limbs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.label: Aplasia/Hypoplasia involving the musculature of the upper arm
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.definition: Absence or underdevelopment of the muscles of the upper arm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000146.label: Abnormal morphology of the pelvis musculature

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.label: Sex-limited expression
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.definition: Sex limitation is used to refer to a monogenic trait linked to an autosomal locus in which the phenotypic effects of allelic differences are expressed only in one sex.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.label: Aplasia/Hypoplasia of the musculature of the pelvis
Sclerotic scapulae
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.definition: Increased density of the bony tissue of the scapula.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.label: Male-limited expression
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.definition: Used to refer to a monogenic trait linked to an autosomal locus in which the phenotypic effects of allelic differences are expressed only in the male sex.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.label: Delayed closure of the anterior fontanelle
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.definition: A delay in closure (ossification) of the anterior fontanelle, which generally undergoes closure around the 18th month of life.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.label: Compensatory chin elevation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000147.definition: A tendency to hold the chin elevated by about 20 to 30 degrees to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000148.label: Freckling
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000148.definition: The presence of an increased number of freckles, small circular spots on the skin that are darker than the surrounding skin because of deposits of melanin.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000148.label: Subcutaneous nodule
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000148.definition: Slightly elevated lesions on or in the skin with a diameter of over 5 mm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000148.label: Eye poking
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000148.definition: Repetitive pressing, poking, and/or rubbing in the eyes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000148.label: Posterior vitreous detachment
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000148.definition: Separation of the vitreous humor from the retina.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000149.label: Congenital fibrosis of extraocular muscles
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000149.definition: Congenital non-progressive ophthalmoplegia with multiple extraocular muscle restrictions. Typically, there is ptosis and variable degrees of restriction of horizontal and vertical eye movements.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000149.label: Axenfeld anomaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000149.definition: Axenfeld's anomaly is a bilateral disorder characterized by a prominent, anteriorly displaced Schwalbe's line (posterior embryotoxon) and peripheral iris strands which span the anterior chamber angle to attach to Schwalbe's line.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000149.label: Falciform retinal fold
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000149.definition: An area of the retina that is buckled so that a sector-shaped sheet of retina lies in front of the normal retina. This feature is of congenital onset.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000149.label: Carpal bone hypoplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000149.definition: Underdevelopment of one or more carpal bones.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000150.label: Broad finger
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000150.definition: Increased width of a non-thumb digit of the hand.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000150.label: Failure to thrive
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000150.definition: Failure to thrive (FTT) refers to a child whose physical growth is substantially below the norm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.label: Growth delay
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.definition: A deficiency or slowing down of growth pre- and postnatally.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.label: Intrauterine growth retardation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.definition: An abnormal restriction of fetal growth with fetal weight below the tenth percentile for gestational age.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.label: Obesity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.definition: Accumulation of substantial excess body fat.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.label: Small for gestational age
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.definition: Smaller than normal size according to sex and gestational age related norms, defined as a weight below the 10th percentile for the gestational age.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.label: Disproportionate tall stature
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000151.definition: A tall and slim body build with increased arm span to height ratio (>1.05) and a reduced upper-to-lower segment ratio (<0.85), i.e., unusually long arms and legs. The extremities as well as the hands and feet are unusually slim.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000152.label: Large for gestational age
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000152.definition: The term large for gestational age applies to babies whose birth weight lies above the 90th percentile for that gestational age.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000152.label: Death in infancy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000152.definition: Death within the first 24 months of life.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000152.label: Hemihypertrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000152.definition: Overgrowth of only one side of the body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.label: Mild postnatal growth retardation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.definition: A mild degree of slow or limited growth after birth, being between two and three standard deviations below age- and sex-related norms.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.label: Slender build
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.definition: Asthenic habitus refers to a slender build with long limbs, an angular profile, and prominent muscles or bones.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.label: Umbilical hernia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.definition: Protrusion of abdominal contents through a defect in the abdominal wall musculature around the umbilicus. Skin and subcutaneous tissue overlie the defect.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.label: Protuberant abdomen
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.definition: A thrusting or bulging out of the abdomen.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.label: Omphalocele
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000153.definition: A midline anterior incomplete closure of the abdominal wall in which there is herniation of the abdominal viscera into the base of the abdominal cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.label: Diastasis recti
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.definition: A separation of the rectus abdominis muscle into right and left halves (which are normally joined at the midline at the linea alba).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.label: Ascites
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.definition: Accumulation of fluid in the peritoneal cavity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.label: Gastroschisis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.definition: A type of congenital ventral incomplete closure of the abdominal wall in which the intestines and sometimes other organs extend freely into the amniotic fluid space through a small opening in the abdomen, usually to the right of the umbilicus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.label: Abnormal rib cage morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.definition: A morphological anomaly of the rib cage.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.label: Overgrowth
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000154.definition: Excessive postnatal growth which may comprise increased weight, increased length, and/or increased head circumference.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000155.label: Abnormal umbilicus morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000155.definition: An abnormality of the structure or appearance of the umbilicus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000155.label: Barrel-shaped chest
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000155.definition: A rounded, bulging chest that resembles the shape of a barrel. That is, there is an increased anteroposterior diameter and usually some degree of kyphosis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000155.label: Asymmetry of the thorax
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000155.definition: Lack of symmetry between the left and right halves of the thorax.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000155.label: Decreased fetal movement
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000155.definition: An abnormal reduction in quantity or strength of fetal movements.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.label: Abnormality of the amniotic fluid
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.definition: Abnormality of the amniotic fluid, which is the fluid contained in the amniotic sac surrounding the developing fetus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.label: Polyhydramnios
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.definition: The presence of excess amniotic fluid in the uterus during pregnancy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.label: Oligohydramnios
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.definition: Diminished amniotic fluid volume in pregnancy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.label: Fetal polyuria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.definition: Abnormally increased production of urine by the fetus resulting in polyhydramnios.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.label: Widely-spaced maxillary central incisors
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000156.definition: Increased distance between the maxillary central permanent incisor tooth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000157.label: Multiple impacted teeth
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000157.definition: The presence of multiple impacted teeth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000157.label: Macrodontia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000157.definition: Increased size of the teeth, which can be defined as a mesiodistal tooth diameter (width) more than 2 SD above mean for age. Alternatively, an apparently increased maximum width of the tooth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000157.label: Abnormality of the integument
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000157.definition: An abnormality of the integument, which consists of the skin and the superficial fascia.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000157.label: Primary hypercortisolism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000157.definition: Hypercortisolemia associated with a primary defect of the adrenal gland leading to overproduction of cortisol.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000158.label: Recurrent skin infections
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000158.definition: Infections of the skin that happen multiple times.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000158.label: Redundant skin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000158.definition: Loose and sagging skin often associated with loss of skin elasticity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000158.label: Rotary nystagmus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000158.definition: A form of nystagmus in which the eyeball makes rotary motions around the axis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000158.label: Vesicovaginal fistula
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000158.definition: The presence of a fistula connecting the urinary bladder to the vagina.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.label: Bell-shaped thorax
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.definition: The rib cage has the shape of a wide mouthed bell. That is, the superior portion of the rib cage is constricted, followed by a convex region, and the inferior portion of the rib cage expands again to have a large diameter.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.label: Selective tooth agenesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.definition: Agenesis specifically affecting one of the classes incisor, premolar, or molar.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.label: Maxillary lateral incisor microdontia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.definition: Decreased size of the maxillary permanent incisor.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.label: Alopecia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.definition: A noncongenital process of hair loss, which may progress to partial or complete baldness.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.label: Concave nail
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000159.definition: The natural longitudinal (posterodistal) convex arch is not present or is inverted.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000160.label: Laryngomalacia
