http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000208.definition: An abnormality of the respiratory system, which include the airways, lungs, and the respiratory muscles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000208.label: Abnormality of the upper respiratory tract
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000208.definition: An abnormality of the upper respiratory tract.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000208.label: Abnormal lung morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000208.definition: Any structural anomaly of the lung.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.label: Pneumonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.definition: Inflammation of any part of the lung parenchyma.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.label: Restrictive ventilatory defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.definition: A functional defect characterized by reduced total lung capacity (TLC) not associated with abnormalities of expiratory airflow or airway resistance. Spirometrically, a restrictive defect is defined as FEV1 (forced expiratory volume in 1 second) and FVC (forced vital capacity) less than 80 per cent. Restrictive lung disease may be caused by alterations in lung parenchyma or because of a disease of the pleura, chest wall, or neuromuscular apparatus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.label: Pulmonary arterial hypertension
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.definition: Pulmonary hypertension is defined mean pulmonary artery pressure of 25mmHg or more and pulmonary capillary wedge pressure of 15mmHg or less when measured by right heart catheterisation at rest and in a supine position.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.label: Dyspnea
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.definition: Difficult or labored breathing. Dyspnea is a subjective feeling only the patient can rate, e.g., on a Borg scale.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.label: Respiratory distress
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.definition: Respiratory distress is objectively observable as the physical or emotional consequences from the experience of dyspnea. The physical presentation of respiratory distress is generally referred to as labored breathing, while the sensation of respiratory distress is called shortness of breath or dyspnea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.label: Asthma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000209.definition: Asthma is characterized by increased responsiveness of the tracheobronchial tree to multiple stimuli, leading to narrowing of the air passages with resultant dyspnea, cough, and wheezing.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.label: Recurrent aspiration pneumonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.definition: Increased susceptibility to aspiration pneumonia, defined as pneumonia due to breathing in foreign material, as manifested by a medical history of repeated episodes of aspiration pneumonia.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.label: Abnormal lung lobation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.definition: A developmental defect in the formation of pulmonary lobes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.label: Abnormal pleura morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary pleura, the thin, transparent membrane which covers the lungs and lines the inside of the chest walls.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.label: Apnea
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.definition: Lack of breathing with no movement of the respiratory muscles and no exchange of air in the lungs. This term refers to a disposition to have recurrent episodes of apnea rather than to a single event.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.label: Hemoptysis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.definition: Coughing up (expectoration) of blood or blood-streaked sputum from the larynx, trachea, bronchi, or lungs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.label: Pneumothorax
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.definition: Accumulation of air in the pleural cavity leading to a partially or completely collapsed lung.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.label: Spontaneous pneumothorax
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000210.definition: Pneumothorax occurring without traumatic injury to the chest or lung.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000211.label: Bronchiectasis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000211.definition: Persistent abnormal dilatation of the bronchi owing to localized and irreversible destruction and widening of the large airways.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000211.label: obsolete Restrictive deficit on pulmonary function testing
Abnormal cerebral ventricle morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000211.definition: Any structural abnormality of the cerebral ventricles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000211.label: Ventriculomegaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000211.definition: An increase in size of the ventricular system of the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.label: Cerebral cortical atrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.definition: Atrophy of the cortex of the cerebrum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.label: Generalized non-motor (absence) seizure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.definition: A generalized non-motor (absence) seizure is a type of a type of dialeptic seizure that is of electrographically generalized onset. It is a generalized seizure characterised by an interruption of activities, a blank stare, and usually the person will be unresponsive when spoken to. Any ictal motor phenomena are minor in comparison to these non-motor features.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.label: Generalized myoclonic seizure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.definition: A generalized myoclonic seizure is a type of generalized motor seizure characterised by bilateral, sudden, brief (<100 ms) involuntary single or multiple contraction of muscles or muscle groups of variable topography (axial, proximal limb, distal). Myoclonus is less regularly repetitive and less sustained than is clonus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.label: Polymicrogyria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.definition: Polymicrogyria is a congenital malformation of the cerebral cortex characterized by abnormal cortical layering (lamination) and an excessive number of small gyri (folds).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.label: Abnormal upper motor neuron morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000212.definition: Any structural anomaly that affects the upper motor neuron.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.label: Episodic ataxia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.definition: Periodic spells of incoordination and imbalance, that is, episodes of ataxia typically lasting from 10 minutes to several hours or days.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.label: Porencephalic cyst
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.definition: A cavity within the cerebral hemisphere, filled with cerebrospinal fluid, that communicates directly with the ventricular system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.label: Status epilepticus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.definition: Status epilepticus is a type of prolonged seizure resulting either from the failure of the mechanisms responsible for seizure termination or from the initiation of mechanisms which lead to abnormally prolonged seizures (after time point t1). It is a condition that can have long-term consequences (after time point t2), including neuronal death, neuronal injury, and alteration of neuronal networks, depending on the type and duration of seizures.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.label: Basal ganglia calcification
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.definition: The presence of calcium deposition affecting one or more structures of the basal ganglia.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.label: Broad-based gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.definition: An abnormal gait pattern in which persons stand and walk with their feet spaced widely apart. This is often a component of cerebellar ataxia.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.label: Subarachnoid hemorrhage
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.definition: Hemorrhage occurring between the arachnoid mater and the pia mater.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.label: Arrhinencephaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000213.definition: A defect of development of the brain characterized by congenital absence of the part of the brain that includes the olfactory bulbs, tracts, and other structures associated with the sense of smell.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.label: Ischemic stroke
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.definition: Acute ischemic stroke (AIS) is defined by the sudden loss of blood flow to an area of the brain with the resulting loss of neurologic function. It is caused by thrombosis or embolism that occludes a cerebral vessel supplying a specific area of the brain. During a vessel occlusion, there is a core area where damage to the brain is irreversible and an area of penumbra where the brain has lost function owing to decreased blood flow but is not irreversibly injured.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.label: Abnormal spinal cord morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.definition: A structural abnormality of the spinal cord (myelon).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.label: Tethered cord
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.definition: During normal embryological development, the spinal cord first occupies the entire length of the vertebral column but goes on to assume a position at the level of L1 due to differential growth of the conus medullaris and the vertebral column. The filum terminale is a slender, threadlike structure that remains after the normal regression of the distal embryonic spinal cord and attaches the spinal cord to the coccyx. A tethered cord results if there is a thickened rope-like filum terminale which anchors the cord at the level of L2 or below, potentially causing neurologic signs owing to abnormal tension on the spinal cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.label: Frontotemporal dementia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.definition: A dementia associated with degeneration of the frontotemporal lobe and clinically associated with personality and behavioral changes such as disinhibition, apathy, and lack of insight. The hallmark feature of frontotemporal dementia is the presentation with focal syndromes such as progressive language dysfunction, or aphasia, or behavioral changes characteristic of frontal lobe disorders.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.label: Hypophosphatemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.definition: An abnormally decreased phosphate concentration in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.label: Hyperuricemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000214.definition: An abnormally high level of uric acid in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.label: Increased serum lactate
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.definition: Abnormally increased level of blood lactate (2-hydroxypropanoic acid). Lactate is produced from pyruvate by lactate dehydrogenase during normal metabolism. The terms lactate and lactic acid are often used interchangeably but lactate (the component measured in blood) is strictly a weak base whereas lactic acid is the corresponding acid. Lactic acidosis is often used clinically to describe elevated lactate but should be reserved for cases where there is a corresponding acidosis (pH below 7.35).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.label: Hyperproteinemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.definition: An increased concentration of proteins in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.label: Hyperkalemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.definition: An abnormally increased potassium concentration in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.label: Hyperglycinemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.definition: An elevated concentration of glycine in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.label: Hypertriglyceridemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.definition: An abnormal increase in the level of triglycerides in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.label: Homocystinuria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.definition: An increased concentration of homocystine in the urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.label: Azotemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.definition: An increased concentration of nitrogen compounds in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.label: Heparan sulfate excretion in urine
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000215.definition: An increased concentration of heparan sulfates in the urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Hyperhomocystinemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: An increased concentration of homocystine in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Hyperlysinemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: An increased concentration of lysine in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Low posterior hairline
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: Hair on the neck extends more inferiorly than usual.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Nail dysplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the nail.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Pterygium of nails
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: Inward advance of skin over the nail plate.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Impaired vibration sensation in the lower limbs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration in the legs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Abnormality of speech or vocalization
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: Abnormalities in the sound of a person's speech or vocalization are not necessarily associated with a known physical cause or due to stuttering or stammering.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Scanning speech
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: An abnormal pattern of speech in which the words are as if measured or scanned; there is a pause after every syllable, and the syllables themselves are pronounced slowly.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.label: Clonus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000216.definition: A series of rhythmic and involuntary muscle contractions (at a frequency of about 5 to 7 Hz) that occur in response to an abruptly applied and sustained stretch.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000217.label: Gliosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000217.definition: Gliosis is the focal proliferation of glial cells in the central nervous system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000217.label: Postural instability
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000217.definition: A tendency to fall or the inability to keep oneself from falling; imbalance. The retropulsion test is widely regarded as the gold standard to evaluate postural instability, Use of the retropulsion test includes a rapid balance perturbation in the backward direction, and the number of balance correcting steps (or total absence thereof) is used to rate the degree of postural instability. Healthy subjects correct such perturbations with either one or two large steps, or without taking any steps, hinging rapidly at the hips while swinging the arms forward as a counterweight. In patients with balance impairment, balance correcting steps are often too small, forcing patients to take more than two steps. Taking three or more steps is generally considered to be abnormal, and taking more than five steps is regarded as being clearly abnormal. Markedly affected patients continue to step backward without ever regaining their balance and must be caught by the examiner (this would be called true retropulsion). Even more severely affected patients fail to correct entirely, and fall backward like a pushed toy soldier, without taking any corrective steps.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000217.label: Postural tremor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000217.definition: A type of tremors that is triggered by holding a limb in a fixed position.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000217.label: Spinal cord compression
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000217.definition: External mechanical compression of the spinal cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.label: Neurodegeneration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.definition: Progressive loss of neural cells and tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.label: Cerebral edema
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.definition: Abnormal accumulation of fluid in the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.label: Phonophobia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.definition: An abnormally heightened sensitivity to loud sounds.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.label: Neurofibrillary tangles
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.definition: Pathological protein aggregates formed by hyperphosphorylation of a microtubule-associated protein known as tau, causing it to aggregate in an insoluble form.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.label: Apraxia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.definition: A defect in the understanding of complex motor commands and in the execution of certain learned movements, i.e., deficits in the cognitive components of learned movements.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.label: Intellectual disability, profound
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.definition: Profound mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) below 20.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.label: Delayed CNS myelination
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000218.definition: Delayed myelination in the central nervous system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.label: Choroid plexus cyst
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.definition: A cyst occurring within the choroid plexus within a cerebral ventricle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.label: Progressive spasticity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.definition: Spasticity that increases in degree with time.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.label: Pseudobulbar behavioral symptoms
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.definition: Individuals with Pseudobulbar signs often also demonstrate abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.label: Delayed gross motor development
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.definition: A type of motor delay characterized by a delay in acquiring the ability to control the large muscles of the body for walking, running, sitting, and crawling.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.label: Dysgenesis of the cerebellar vermis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.definition: Defective development of the vermis of cerebellum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.label: Generalized-onset seizure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.definition: A generalized-onset seizure is a type of seizure originating at some point within, and rapidly engaging, bilaterally distributed networks. The networks may include cortical and subcortical structures but not necessarily the entire cortex.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.label: Dilated fourth ventricle
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000219.definition: An abnormal dilatation of the fourth cerebral ventricle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.label: Pseudobulbar signs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.definition: Pseudobulbar signs result from injury to an upper motor neuron lesion to the corticobulbar pathways in the pyramidal tract. Patients have difficulty chewing, swallowing and demonstrate slurred speech (often initial presentation) as well as abnormal behavioral symptoms such as inappropriate emotional outbursts of uncontrolled laughter or weeping etc.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.label: Pleural effusion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.definition: The presence of an excessive amount of fluid in the pleural cavity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.label: Respiratory paralysis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.definition: Inability to move the muscles of respiration.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.label: Pulmonary embolism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.definition: An embolus (that is, an abnormal particle circulating in the blood) located in the pulmonary artery and thereby blocking blood circulation to the lung. Usually the embolus is a blood clot that has developed in an extremity (for instance, a deep venous thrombosis), detached, and traveled through the circulation before becoming trapped in the pulmonary artery.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.label: Recurrent respiratory infections
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.definition: An increased susceptibility to respiratory infections as manifested by a history of recurrent respiratory infections.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.label: Pulmonary fibrosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.definition: Replacement of normal lung tissues by fibroblasts and collagen.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.label: Diffuse reticular or finely nodular infiltrations
Coarse hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.definition: Hair shafts are rough in texture.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.label: Sparse scalp hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000220.definition: Decreased number of hairs per unit area of skin of the scalp.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.label: White forelock
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.definition: A triangular depigmented region of white hairs located in the anterior midline of the scalp.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.label: Fine hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.definition: Hair that is fine or thin to the touch.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.label: Sparse axillary hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.definition: Reduced number or density of axillary hair.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.label: Premature graying of hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.definition: Development of gray hair at a younger than normal age.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.label: Slow-growing hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.definition: Hair whose growth is slower than normal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.label: Facial hypertrichosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000221.definition: Excessive, increased hair growth located in the facial region.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000222.label: Melanin pigment aggregation in hair shafts
Woolly hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000222.definition: The term woolly hair refers to an abnormal variant of hair that is fine, with tightly coiled curls, and often hypopigmented. Optical microscopy may reveal the presence of tight spirals and a clear diameter reduction as compared with normal hair. Electron microscopy may show flat, oval hair shafts with reduced transversal diameter.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000222.label: Sparse pubic hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000222.definition: Reduced number or density of pubic hair.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000222.label: White eyebrow
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000222.definition: White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyebrow.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000222.label: White eyelashes
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000222.definition: White color (lack of pigmentation) of the eyelashes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.label: Generalized hirsutism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.definition: Abnormally increased hair growth over much of the entire body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.label: Patchy alopecia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.definition: Transient, non-scarring hair loss and preservation of the hair follicle located in in well-defined patches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.label: Early balding
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.definition: Loss of scalp hair at an earlier than normal age.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.label: Pili canaliculi
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.definition: A characteristic triangular, kidney- or heat-shaped diameter of hair shafts with typical longitudinal canalicular deformation as observable by scanning electron microscopy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.label: Frontal upsweep of hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000223.definition: Upward and/or sideward growth of anterior hair.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.label: Hepatomegaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.definition: Abnormally increased size of the liver.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.label: Abnormal intestine morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.definition: An abnormality of the intestine. The closely related term enteropathy is used to refer to any disease of the intestine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.label: Protein-losing enteropathy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.definition: Abnormal loss of protein from the digestive tract related to excessive leakage of plasma proteins into the lumen of the gastrointestinal tract.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.label: Abnormal small intestine morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.definition: A structural abnormality of the small intestine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.label: Meckel diverticulum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.definition: Meckel's diverticulum is a congenital diverticulum located in the distal ileum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.label: Abnormal duodenum morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.definition: An abnormality of the duodenum, i.e., the first section of the small intestine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.label: Duodenal atresia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.definition: A developmental defect resulting in complete obliteration of the duodenal lumen, that is, an abnormal closure of the duodenum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.label: Melena
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000224.definition: The passage of blackish, tarry feces associated with gastrointestinal hemorrhage. Melena occurs if the blood remains in the colon long enough for it to be broken down by colonic bacteria. One degradation product, hematin, imbues the stool with a blackish color. Thus, melena generally occurs with bleeding from the upper gastrointestinal tract (e.g., stomach ulcers or duodenal ulcers), since the blood usually remains in the gut for a longer period of time than with lower gastrointestinal bleeding.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.label: Abnormal large intestine morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.definition: Any abnormality of the large intestine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.label: Aganglionic megacolon
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.definition: An abnormality resulting from a lack of intestinal ganglion cells (i.e., an aganglionic section of bowel) that results in bowel obstruction with enlargement of the colon.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.label: Colonic diverticula
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.definition: The presence of multiple diverticula of the colon.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.label: Intermittent diarrhea
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.definition: Repeated episodes of diarrhea separated by periods without diarrhea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.label: Chronic rhinitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000225.definition: Chronic inflammation of the nasal mucosa.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.label: Exaggerated cupid's bow
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.definition: More pronounced paramedian peaks and median notch of the Cupid's bow.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.label: Focal clonic seizure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.definition: A focal clonic seizure is a type of focal motor seizure characterized by sustained rhythmic jerking, that is regularly repetitive.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.label: Exaggerated startle response
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.definition: An exaggerated startle reaction in response to a sudden unexpected visual or acoustic stimulus, or a quick movement near the face.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.label: Paroxysmal dystonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.definition: A form of dystonia characterized by episodes of dystonia (often hemidystonia or generalized) lasting from minutes to hours. There are no dystonic symptoms between episodes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.label: Abnormality of neuronal migration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000226.definition: An abnormality resulting from an anomaly of neuronal migration, i.e., of the process by which neurons travel from their origin to their final position in the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000227.label: Abnormality of the autonomic nervous system
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000227.definition: An abnormality of the autonomic nervous system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000227.label: Horner syndrome
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000227.definition: An abnormality resulting from a lesion of the sympathetic nervous system characterized by a combination of unilateral ptosis, miosis, and often ipsilateral hypohidrosis and conjunctival injection.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.label: Enlarged cisterna magna
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.definition: Increase in size of the cisterna magna, one of three principal openings in the subarachnoid space between the arachnoid and pia mater, located between the cerebellum and the dorsal surface of the medulla oblongata.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.label: Gray matter heterotopia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.definition: Heterotopia or neuronal heterotopia are macroscopic clusters of misplaced neurons (gray matter), most often situated along the ventricular walls or within the subcortical white matter.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.label: Global brain atrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.definition: Unlocalized atrophy of the brain with decreased total brain matter volume and increased ventricular size.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.label: Fair hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.definition: A lesser degree of hair pigmentation than would otherwise be expected.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.label: Alopecia universalis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000228.definition: Loss of all hair on the entire body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000229.label: Poliosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000229.definition: Circumscribed depigmentation of the hair of the head or the eyelashes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000229.label: Frontal balding
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000229.definition: Absence of hair in the anterior midline and/or parietal areas.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000229.label: Progressive hypotrichosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000229.definition: Progressively reduced or lacking hair growth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000229.label: Brittle hair
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000229.definition: Fragile, easily breakable hair, i.e., with reduced tensile strength.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.label: Mutism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.definition: Inability to speak or communicate verbally past the age of typical language development.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.label: Hemiplegia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.definition: Paralysis (complete loss of muscle function) in the arm, leg, and in some cases the face on one side of the body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.label: Akinesia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.definition: Inability to initiate changes in activity or movement and to perform ordinary volitional movements rapidly and easily.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.label: Athetosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.definition: A slow, continuous, involuntary writhing movement that prevents maintenance of a stable posture. Athetosis involves continuous smooth movements that appear random and are not composed of recognizable sub-movements or movement fragments. In contrast to chorea, in athetosis, the same regions of the body are repeatedly involved. Athetosis may worsen with attempts at movement of posture, but athetosis can also occur at rest.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.label: Drooling
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.definition: Habitual flow of saliva out of the mouth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.label: Chiari malformation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000230.definition: Chiari malformation consists of a downward displacement of the cerebellar tonsils and the medulla through the foramen magnum, sometimes causing hydrocephalus as a result of obstruction of CSF outflow.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000231.label: Clumsiness
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000231.definition: Lack of physical coordination resulting in an abnormal tendency to drop items or bump into objects.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000231.label: Degeneration of the lateral corticospinal tracts
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000231.definition: Deterioration of the tissues of the lateral corticospinal tracts.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000231.label: Headache
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000231.definition: Cephalgia, or pain sensed in various parts of the head, not confined to the area of distribution of any nerve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.label: Vertigo
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.definition: An abnormal sensation of spinning while the body is actually stationary.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.label: Resting tremor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.definition: A resting tremor occurs when muscles are at rest and becomes less noticeable or disappears when the affected muscles are moved. Resting tremors are often slow and coarse.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.label: Anencephaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.definition: Anencephaly is a developmental anomaly characterized by a fetus that has no calvarium, with a lack of most or all of the fetus' brain tissue. Anencephaly belongs to a collective group known as neural tube defects (NTD) and is a result of the neural tube failing to close in its rostral end during fetal development.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.label: Hydranencephaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.definition: A defect of development of the brain characterized by replacement of greater portions of the cerebral hemispheres and the corpus striatum by cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) and glial tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.label: Drowsiness
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000232.definition: Abnormal feeling of sleepiness or difficulty staying awake.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.label: Paroxysmal drowsiness
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.definition: A neurological disorder marked by a sudden recurrent uncontrollable compulsion to sleep

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.label: Recurrent paroxysmal headache
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.definition: Repeated episodes of headache with rapid onset, reaching a peak within minutes and of short duration (less than one hour) with pain that is throbbing, pulsating, or bursting in quality.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.label: Lack of peer relationships
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.definition: The state of not having relationships with peers outside of school or organized activity appropriate to developmental level. This may be caused by behavioral or physical barriers.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.label: Motor deterioration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.definition: Loss of previously present motor (i.e., movement) abilities.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.label: Abnormal cerebellar vermis morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.definition: An anomaly of the vermis of cerebellum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.label: Agenesis of cerebellar vermis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.definition: Congenital absence of the vermis of cerebellum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.label: Abnormal caudate nucleus morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000233.definition: Any structural abnormality of the caudate nucleus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.label: Cervical cord compression
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.definition: Compression of the spinal cord in the cervical region, generally manifested by paresthesias and numbness, weakness, difficulty walking, abnormalities of coordination, and neck pain or stiffness.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.label: Intellectual disability, moderate
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.definition: Moderate mental retardation is defined as an intelligence quotient (IQ) in the range of 35-49.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.label: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.definition: A form of hydrocephalus characterized by enlarged cerebral ventricles and normal cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure upon lumbar puncture.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.label: Action tremor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.definition: A tremor present when the limbs are active, either when outstretched in a certain position or throughout a voluntary movement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.label: Head tremor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.definition: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting head movement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.label: Focal aware seizure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000234.definition: A type of focal-onset seizure in which awareness is preserved. Awareness during a seizure is defined as the patient being fully aware of themself and their environment throughout the seizure, even if immobile.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000235.label: Leukoencephalopathy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000235.definition: This term describes abnormality of the white matter of the cerebrum resulting from damage to the myelin sheaths of nerve cells.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000235.label: EEG abnormality
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000235.definition: Abnormality observed by electroencephalogram (EEG), which is used to record of the brain's spontaneous electrical activity from multiple electrodes placed on the scalp.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000235.label: Memory impairment
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000235.definition: An impairment of memory as manifested by a reduced ability to remember things such as dates and names, and increased forgetfulness.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000235.label: Writer's cramp
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000235.definition: A focal dystonia of the fingers, hand, and/or forearm that appears when the affected person attempts to do a task that requires fine motor movements such as writing or playing a musical instrument.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.label: Sleep abnormality
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.definition: An abnormal pattern in the quality, quantity, or characteristics of sleep.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.label: Psychomotor deterioration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.definition: Loss of previously present mental and motor abilities.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.label: Shuffling gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.definition: A type of gait (walking) characterized by by dragging one's feet along or without lifting the feet fully from the ground.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.label: Abnormal lower motor neuron morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.definition: Any structural anomaly of the lower motor neuron.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.label: Visual hallucination
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000236.definition: Visual perception in the absence of a visual stimulus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.label: Normal interictal EEG
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.definition: Lack of observable abnormal electroencephalographic (EEG) patterns in an individual with a history of seizures. About half of individuals with epilepsy show interictal epileptiform discharges upon the first investigation. The yield can be increased by repeated studies, sleep studies, or by ambulatory EEG recordings over 24 hours. Normal interictal EEG is a sign that can be useful in the differential diagnosis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.label: Febrile seizure (within the age range of 3 months to 6 years)
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.definition: A febrile seizure is any type of seizure (most often a generalized tonic-clonic seizure) occurring with fever (at least 38 degrees Celsius) but in the absence of central nervous system infection, severe metabolic disturbance or other alternative precipitant in children between the ages of 3 months and 6 years.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.label: Hypokinesia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.definition: Abnormally diminished motor activity. In contrast to paralysis, hypokinesia is not characterized by a lack of motor strength, but rather by a poverty of movement. The typical habitual movements (e.g., folding the arms, crossing the legs) are reduced in frequency.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.label: Developmental regression
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.definition: Loss of developmental skills, as manifested by loss of developmental milestones.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.label: Hand tremor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000237.definition: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting the hand.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.label: Fasciculations
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.definition: Fasciculations are observed as small, local, involuntary muscle contractions (twitching) visible under the skin. Fasciculations result from increased irritability of an axon (which in turn is often a manifestation of disease of a motor neuron). This leads to sporadic discharges of all the muscle fibers controlled by the axon in isolation from other motor units.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.label: Aphasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.definition: An acquired language impairment of some or all of the abilities to produce or comprehend speech and to read or write.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.label: Infectious encephalitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.definition: A disorder of the brain caused by an infectious agent that presents with fever, headache, and an altered level of consciousness. There may also be focal or multifocal neurologic deficits, and focal or generalized seizure activity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.label: Focal impaired awareness seizure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.definition: Focal impaired awareness seizure (or focal seizure with impaired or lost awareness) is a type of focal-onset seizure characterized by some degree (which may be partial) of impairment of the person's awareness of themselves or their surroundings at any point during the seizure.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.label: Paraparesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.definition: Weakness or partial paralysis in the lower limbs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.label: Cavum septum pellucidum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000238.definition: If the two laminae of the septum pellucidum are not fused then a fluid-filled space or cavum is present. The cavum septum pellucidum is present at birth but usually obliterates by the age of 3 to 6 months. It is up to 1cm in width and the walls are parallel. It is an enclosed space and is not part of the ventricular system or connected with the subarachnoid space.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000239.label: EEG with polyspike wave complexes
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000239.definition: The presence of complexes of repetitive spikes and waves in EEG.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000239.label: Cogwheel rigidity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000239.definition: A type of rigidity in which a muscle responds with cogwheellike jerks to the use of constant force in bending the limb (i.e., it gives way in little, repeated jerks when the muscle is passively stretched).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.label: Stroke-like episode
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.definition: No consensus exists on what a stroke-like episode is, but these episodes can be functionally defined as a new neurological deficit, occurring with or without the context of seizures, which last longer than 24 hours.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.label: Positive Romberg sign
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.definition: The patient stands with the feet placed together and balance and is asked to close his or her eyes. A loss of balance upon eye closure is a positive Romberg sign and is interpreted as indicating a deficit in proprioception.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.label: Thickened superior cerebellar peduncle
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.definition: Increased width of the superior cerebellar peduncle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.label: Limb dysmetria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.definition: A type of dysmetria involving the limbs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.label: Cerebral arteriovenous malformation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000240.definition: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.label: Aqueductal stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.definition: Stenosis of the cerebral aqueduct (also known as the mesencephalic duct, aqueductus mesencephali, or aqueduct of Sylvius), which connects the third cerebral ventricle in the diencephalon to the fourth ventricle, which is between the pons and cerebellum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.label: Myokymia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.definition: Myokymia consists of involuntary, fine, continuous, undulating contractions that spread across the affected striated muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.label: Spina bifida
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.definition: Incomplete closure of the embryonic neural tube, whereby some vertebral arches remain unfused and open. The mildest form is spina bifida occulta, followed by meningocele and meningomyelocele.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.label: Leukodystrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.definition: Leukodystrophy refers to deterioration of white matter of the brain resulting from degeneration of myelin sheaths in the CNS. Their basic defect is directly related to the synthesis and maintenance of myelin membranes. Symmetric white matter involvement at MRI is a typical finding in patients with leukodystrophies.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.label: Subependymal cysts
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.definition: Cerebral cysts, usually located in the wall of the caudate nucleus or in the caudothalamic groove. They are found in up to 5.2% of all neonates, using transfontanellar ultrasound in the first days of life.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.label: Abnormal midbrain morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.definition: An abnormality of the midbrain, which has as its parts the tectum, cerebral peduncle, midbrain tegmentum and cerebral aqueduct.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.label: Molar tooth sign on MRI
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000241.definition: An abnormal appearance of the midbrain in axial magnetic resonance imaging in which the elongated superior cerebellar peduncles give the midbrain an appearance reminiscent of a molar or wisdom tooth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000242.label: Poor head control
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000242.definition: Difficulty to maintain correct position of the head while standing or sitting.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000242.label: Long-tract signs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000242.definition: Long-tract signs refer to symptoms that are attributable to the involvement of the long fiber tracts in the spinal cord, which connect the spinal cord to the brain and mediate spinal and motor functions.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000242.label: Anarthria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000242.definition: A defect in the motor ability that enables speech.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000242.label: Expressive aphasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000242.definition: Impairment of expressive language and relative preservation of receptive language abilities. That is, the patient understands language (speech, writing) but cannot express it.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000243.label: Meningocele
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000243.definition: Protrusion of the meninges through a defect of the skull or vertebral column.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000243.label: Occipital meningocele
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000243.definition: A herniation of meninges through a congenital bone defect in the skull in the occipital region.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000244.label: Dyscalculia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000244.definition: A specific learning disability involving mathematics and arithmetic.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000244.label: Hypothalamic hamartoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000244.definition: The presence of a hamartoma of the hypothalamus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000244.label: Tetraplegia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000244.definition: Paralysis of all four limbs, and trunk of the body below the level of an associated injury to the spinal cord. The etiology of quadriplegia is similar to that of paraplegia except that the lesion is in the cervical spinal cord rather than in the thoracic or lumbar segments of the spinal cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000244.label: Astrocytosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000244.definition: Proliferation of astrocytes in the area of a lesion of the central nervous system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000245.label: Abnormal motor neuron morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000245.definition: Any structural anomaly that affects the motor neuron.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000245.label: Limb dystonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000245.definition: A type of dystonia (abnormally increased muscular tone causing fixed abnormal postures) that affects muscles of the limbs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000245.label: Abnormal globus pallidus morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000245.definition: An abnormality of the globus pallidus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000245.label: Eye of the tiger anomaly of globus pallidus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000245.definition: The presence, on T2-weighted magnetic resonance imaging, of markedly low signal intensity of the globus pallidus that surrounds a central region of high signal intensity in the anteromedial globus pallidus, producing an eye-of-the-tiger appearance. The sign is thought to represent iron accumulation in the globus pallidus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000246.label: Distal muscle weakness
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000246.definition: Reduced strength of the musculature of the distal extremities.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000246.label: Dense calcifications in the cerebellar dentate nucleus
Language impairment
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000246.definition: Language impairment is a deficit in comprehension or production of language that includes reduced vocabulary, limited sentence structure, or impairments in written or spoken communication. Language abilities are substantially and quantifiably below age expectations.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000246.label: Spastic dysarthria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000246.definition: A type of dysarthria related to bilateral damage of the upper motor neuron tracts of the pyramidal and extra- pyramidal tracts. Speech of affected individuals is slow, effortful, and has a harsh vocal quality.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000247.label: Small cerebral cortex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000247.definition: Reduced size of the cerebral cortex.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000247.label: Expressive language delay
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000247.definition: A delay in the acquisition of the ability to use language to communicate needs, wishes, or thoughts.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000247.label: Myelomeningocele
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000247.definition: Protrusion of the meninges and portions of the spinal cord through a defect of the vertebral column.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000247.label: Primitive reflex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000247.definition: The primitive reflexes are a group of behavioural motor responses which are found in normal early development, are subsequently inhibited, but may be released from inhibition by cerebral, usually frontal, damage. They are thus part of a broader group of reflexes which reflect release phenomena, such as exaggerated stretch reflexes and extensor plantars. They do however involve more complex motor responses than such simple stretch reflexes, and are often a normal feature in the neonate or infant.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000248.label: Hepatic encephalopathy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000248.definition: Central nervous system dysfunction in association with liver failure and characterized clinically (depending on degree of severity) by lethargy, confusion, nystagmus, decorticate posturing, spasticity, and bilateral Babinski reflexes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000248.label: Myotonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000248.definition: An involuntary and painless delay in the relaxation of skeletal muscle following contraction or electrical stimulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000248.label: Hyperkinetic movements
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000248.definition: Motor hyperactivity with excessive movement of muscles of the body as a whole.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000248.label: Acute leukemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000248.definition: A clonal (malignant) hematopoietic disorder with an acute onset, affecting the bone marrow and the peripheral blood. The malignant cells show minimal differentiation and are called blasts, either myeloid blasts (myeloblasts) or lymphoid blasts (lymphoblasts).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.label: Increased CSF lactate
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.definition: Increased concentration of lactate in the cerebrospinal fluid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.label: Spasticity of facial muscles
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.definition: Spasticity of one or more muscles innervated by the facial nerve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.label: Abnormal corticospinal tract morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.definition: Abnormality of the corticospinal tract, which is the chief element of the pyramidal system (the principle motor tract) and is the only direct connection between the cerebrum and the spinal cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.label: Upper motor neuron dysfunction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.definition: A functional anomaly of the upper motor neuron. The upper motor neurons are neurons of the primary motor cortex which project to the brainstem and spinal chord via the corticonuclear, corticobulbar and corticospinal (pyramidal) tracts. They are involved in control of voluntary movements. Dysfunction leads to weakness, impairment of fine motor movements, spasticity, hyperreflexia and abnormal pyramidal signs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.label: Abnormal rapid eye movement sleep
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.definition: Abnormality of REM Sleep are phases of REM sleep are characterized by desynchronized EEG patterns, increases in heart rate and blood pressure, sympathetic activation, and a profound loss of muscle tone except for the eye and middle-ear muscles. There are also phases of rapid eye movements.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.label: Impaired vibratory sensation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000249.definition: A decrease in the ability to perceive vibration. Clinically, this is usually tested with a tuning fork which vibrates at 128 Hz and is applied to bony prominences such as the malleoli at the ankles or the metacarpal-phalangeal joints. There is a slow decay of vibration from the tuning fork. The degree of vibratory sense loss can be crudely estimated by counting the number of seconds that the examiner can perceive the vibration longer than the patient.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.label: Abnormal cerebral white matter morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.definition: An abnormality of the cerebral white matter.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.label: Calcification of the small brain vessels
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.definition: Deposition of calcium salts within small blood vessels of the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.label: Loss of ambulation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.definition: Inability to walk in a person who previous had the ability to walk.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.label: Diffuse cerebral atrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.definition: Diffuse unlocalised atrophy affecting the cerebrum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.label: Semilobar holoprosencephaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.definition: A type of holoprosencephaly in which the left and right frontal and parietal lobes are fused and the interhemispheric fissure is only present posteriorly.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.label: Brainstem dysplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000250.definition: A developmental structural anomaly of the stalk-like part of the brain that comprises the midbrain (aka mesencephalon), the pons (aka pons Varolii), and the medulla oblongata, and connects the cerebral hemispheres with the cervical spinal cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.label: Spastic tetraplegia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.definition: Spastic paralysis affecting all four limbs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.label: Alzheimer disease
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.definition: A degenerative disease of the brain characterized by the insidious onset of dementia. Impairment of memory, judgment, attention span, and problem solving skills are followed by severe apraxia and a global loss of cognitive abilities. The condition primarily occurs after age 60, and is marked pathologically by severe cortical atrophy and the triad of senile plaques, neurofibrillary tangles, and neuropil threads.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.label: Cerebral calcification
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.definition: The presence of calcium deposition within brain structures.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.label: Waddling gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.definition: Weakness of the hip girdle and upper thigh muscles, for instance in myopathies, leads to an instability of the pelvis on standing and walking. If the muscles extending the hip joint are affected, the posture in that joint becomes flexed and lumbar lordosis increases. The patients usually have difficulties standing up from a sitting position. Due to weakness in the gluteus medius muscle, the hip on the side of the swinging leg drops with each step (referred to as Trendelenburg sign). The gait appears waddling. The patients frequently attempt to counteract the dropping of the hip on the swinging side by bending the trunk towards the side which is in the stance phase (in the German language literature this is referred to as Duchenne sign). Similar gait patterns can be caused by orthopedic conditions when the origin and the insertion site of the gluteus medius muscle are closer to each other than normal, for instance due to a posttraumatic elevation of the trochanter or pseudarthrosis of the femoral neck.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.label: Increased intracranial pressure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.definition: An increase of the pressure inside the cranium (skull) and thereby in the brain tissue and cerebrospinal fluid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.label: Abnormal periventricular white matter morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.definition: A structural abnormality of the myelinated axons (white matter) located near the cerebral ventricles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.label: Hypnagogic hallucination
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000251.definition: Hypnagogic hallucinations are brief hallucinations that occur as you are falling asleep.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.label: Hypsarrhythmia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.definition: Hypsarrhythmia is abnormal interictal high amplitude waves and a background of irregular spikes. There is continuous (during wakefulness), high-amplitude (>200 Hz), generalized polymorphic slowing with no organized background and multifocal spikes demonstrated by electroencephalography (EEG).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.label: Areflexia of lower limbs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.definition: Inability to elicit tendon reflexes in the lower limbs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.label: Cataplexy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.definition: A sudden and transient episode of bilateral loss of muscle tone, often triggered by emotions.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.label: Deficit in nonword repetition
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.definition: Impaired ability to repeat non-word sounds. Nonword repetition (NWR) is a measure of short-term phonological memory.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.label: Granulovacuolar degeneration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.definition: Electron-dense granules within double membrane-bound cytoplasmic vacuoles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000252.label: Neuronal loss in central nervous system

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.label: Axial dystonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.definition: A type of dystonia that affects the midline muscles, i.e., the chest, abdominal, and back muscles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.label: Abnormal posturing
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.definition: Involuntary flexion or extension of the arms and legs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.label: Abnormal cortical gyration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.definition: An abnormality of the gyri (i.e., the ridges) of the cerebral cortex of the brain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.label: Abnormal cerebral cortex morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.definition: Any structural abnormality of the cerebral cortex.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.label: Cortical dysplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000253.definition: The presence of developmental dysplasia of the cerebral cortex.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.label: Olivopontocerebellar atrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.definition: Neuronal degeneration in the cerebellum, pontine nuclei, and inferior olivary nucleus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.label: Retrocollis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.definition: A form of torticollis in which the head is drawn back, either due to a permanent contractures of neck extensor muscles, or to a spasmodic contracture.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.label: Patchy demyelination of subcortical white matter
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.definition: Patchy loss of myelin from nerve fibers in the central nervous system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.label: Parkinsonism with favorable response to dopaminergic medication
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.definition: Parkinsonism is a clinical syndrome that is a feature of a number of different diseases, including Parkinson disease itself, other neurodegenerative diseases such as progressive supranuclear palsy, and as a side-effect of some neuroleptic medications. Some but not all individuals with Parkinsonism show responsiveness to dopaminergic medication defined as a substantial reduction of amelioration of the component signs of Parkinsonism (including mainly tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability) upon administration of dopaminergic medication.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.label: Deficit in phonologic short-term memory
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000254.definition: Impaired ability to repeat non-word sounds. The test for nonword repetition involves the repetition of nonsensical words of increasing length and complexity and is regarded as a measure of phonological (speech sound) processing and short-term memory

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000255.label: Highly arched eyebrow
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000255.definition: Increased height of the central portion of the eyebrow, forming a crescent, semicircular, or inverted U shape.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000255.label: Supernumerary nipple
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000255.definition: Presence of more than two nipples.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000256.label: Absent nipple
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000256.definition: Congenital failure to develop, and absence of, the nipple.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000256.label: Low-set nipples
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000256.definition: Placement of the nipples at a lower than normal location.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000256.label: Constrictive pericarditis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000256.definition: Presence of a thickened, fibrotic pericardium that forms a non-compliant shell around the heart, and resulting from chronic inflammation of the pericardium.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000256.label: obsolete Malformation of the heart and great vessels
Intestinal malrotation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000256.definition: An abnormality of the intestinal rotation and fixation that normally occurs during the development of the gut. This can lead to volvulus, or twisting of the intestine that causes obstruction and necrosis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.label: Steatorrhea
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.definition: Greater than normal amounts of fat in the feces. This is a result of malabsorption of lipids in the small intestine and results in frothy foul-smelling fecal matter that floats.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.label: Achalasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.definition: A disorder of esophageal motility characterized by the inability of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax during swallowing and by inadequate or lacking peristalsis in the lower half of the body of the esophagus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.label: Hematochezia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.definition: The passage of fresh (red) blood per anus, usually in or with stools. Most rectal bleeding comes from the colon, rectum, or anus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.label: Episodic abdominal pain
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.definition: An intermittent form of abdominal pain.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.label: Tracheoesophageal fistula
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.definition: An abnormal connection (fistula) between the esophagus and the trachea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.label: Intussusception
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.definition: An abnormality of the intestine in which part of the intestine invaginates (telescopes) into another part of the intestine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.label: Gastroparesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.definition: Decreased strength of the muscle layer of stomach, which leads to a decreased ability to empty the contents of the stomach despite the absence of obstruction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.label: Gastrointestinal dysmotility
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000257.definition: Abnormal intestinal contractions, such as spasms and intestinal paralysis, related to the loss of the ability of the gut to coordinate muscular activity because of endogenous or exogenous causes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.label: Volvulus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.definition: Abnormal twisting of a portion of intestine around itself or around a stalk of mesentery tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.label: Atrophic gastritis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.definition: Atrophic gastritis (AG) is a histopathological entity that is characterized by chronic inflammation of the gastric mucosa with loss of gastric glandular cells and replacement by intestinal-type epithelium, pyloric-type glands, and fibrous tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.label: Colitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.definition: Colitis refers to an inflammation of the colon and is often used to describe an inflammation of the large intestine (colon, cecum and rectum). Colitides may be acute and self-limited or chronic, and broadly fit into the category of digestive diseases.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.label: Projectile vomiting
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.definition: Vomiting that ejects the gastric contents with great force.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.label: Duodenal ulcer
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000258.definition: An erosion of the mucous membrane in a portion of the duodenum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.label: Polyphagia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.definition: A neurological anomaly with gross overeating associated with an abnormally strong desire or need to eat.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.label: Gastric ulcer
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.definition: An ulcer, that is, an erosion of an area of the gastric mucous membrane.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.label: Intestinal lymphangiectasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.definition: Angiectasia of lymph vessels (i.e., dilatation of lymphatic vessels) in the intestines.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.label: Ileus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.definition: Acute obstruction of the intestines preventing passage of the contents of the intestines.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.label: Head titubation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000259.definition: A head tremor of moderate speed (3 to 4 Hz) in the anterior-posterior direction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000260.label: Hyporeflexia of lower limbs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000260.definition: Reduced intensity of muscle tendon reflexes in the lower limbs. Reflexes are elicited by stretching the tendon of a muscle, e.g., by tapping.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000260.label: Paresis of extensor muscles of the big toe
Hepatic necrosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000260.definition: The presence of cell death (necrosis) affecting the liver.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000260.label: Bowel incontinence
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000260.definition: Involuntary fecal soiling in adults and children who have usually already been toilet trained.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000260.label: Celiac disease
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000260.definition: Celiac disease (CD) is an autoimmune condition affecting the small intestine, triggered by the ingestion of gluten, the protein fraction of wheat, barley, and rye. Clinical manifestations of CD are highly variable and include both gastrointestinal and non-gastrointestinal features. The hallmark of CD is an immune-mediated enteropathy. This term is included because the occurence of CD is seen as a feature of a number of other diseases.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.label: Congenital hepatic fibrosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.definition: The presence of fibrosis of that part of the liver with congenital onset.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.label: Biliary cirrhosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.definition: Progressive destruction of the small-to-medium bile ducts of the intrahepatic biliary tree, which leads to progressive cholestasis and often end-stage liver disease.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.label: Hepatic periportal necrosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.definition: A type of hepatic necrosis that is concentrated around the necrosis of hepatocytes localized around the intrahepatic branch of portal vein.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.label: Aortic root aneurysm
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.definition: An abnormal localized widening (dilatation) of the aortic root.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.label: Vascular dilatation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000261.definition: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in the wall of an atery, vein or the heart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.label: Atherosclerosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.definition: A condition characterized by patchy atheromas or atherosclerotic plaques which develop in the walls of medium-sized and large arteries and can lead to arterial stenosis with reduced or blocked blood flow.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.label: Overriding aorta
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.definition: An overriding aorta is a congenital heart defect where the aorta is positioned directly over a ventricular septal defect, instead of over the left ventricle. The result is that the aorta receives some blood from the right ventricle, which reduces the amount of oxygen in the blood. It is one of the four conditions of the Tetralogy of Fallot. The aortic root can be displaced toward the front (anteriorly) or directly above the septal defect, but it is always abnormally located to the right of the root of the pulmonary artery. The degree of override is quite variable, with 5-95% of the valve being connected to the right ventricle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.label: Deep venous thrombosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.definition: Formation of a blot clot in a deep vein. The clot often blocks blood flow, causing swelling and pain. The deep veins of the leg are most often affected.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.label: Venous varicosities of celiac and mesenteric vessels
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.definition: Elongated and tortuous mesenteric veins, which comprise the inferior mesenteric vein and the superior mesenteric vein.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.label: Right aortic arch with mirror image branching
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.definition: The aortic arch crosses the right mainstem bronchus and not the left mainstem bronchus, but does not result in the creation of a vascular ring. The first branch is the left brachiocephalic artery which divides into the left carotid artery and left subclavian artery, the second branch is the right carotid artery, the third branch is the right subclavian artery.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.label: Gastrointestinal arteriovenous malformation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000262.definition: An anomalous configuration of blood vessels that shunts arterial blood directly into veins without passing through the capillaries and that is located in the gastrointestinal tract.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.label: Fat malabsorption
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.definition: Abnormality of the absorption of fat from the gastrointestinal tract.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.label: Arteriosclerosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.definition: Sclerosis (hardening) of the arteries with increased thickness of the wall of arteries as well as increased stiffness and a loss of elasticity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.label: Type IV atherosclerotic lesion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.definition: In type IV atherosclerotic lesions a dense accumulation of extracellular lipid occupies an extensive but well-defined region of the intima. This type of extracellular lipid accumulation is known as the lipid core. A fibrous tissue increase is not a feature, and complications such as defects of the lesion surface and thrombosis are not present. The type IV lesion is also known as atheroma. Type IV is the first lesion considered advanced in this classification because of the severe intimal disorganization caused by the lipid core. The characteristic core appears to develop from an increase and the consequent confluence of the small isolated pools of extracellular lipid that characterize type III lesions. The increase in lipid is believed to result from continued insudation from the plasma. Type IV lesions, when they first appear in younger people, are found in the same locations as adaptive intimal thickenings of the eccentric type. Thus, atheroma is, at least initially, an eccentric lesion.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.label: Dilatation of an abdominal artery
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.definition: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation in an artery that originates from the abdominal aorta.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.label: Cerebral ischemia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.definition: Restriction of arterial blood supply to the brain associated with insufficient oxygenation to support the metabolic requirements of the tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.label: Superficial thrombophlebitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.definition: Inflammation of a superficial vein associated with venous thrombosis (blood clot formation within the vein).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.label: Budd-Chiari syndrome
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_000263.definition: Budd-Chiari syndrome (BCS) is caused by obstruction of hepatic venous outflow at any level from the small hepatic veins to the junction of the inferior vena cava (IVC) with the right atrium, 1 and occurs in 1/100,000 of the general population worldwide. The most common presentation is with ascites, but can range from fulminant hepatic failure (FHF) to asymptomatic forms.
