http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.definition: An abnormality of the circulatory connection between the ventricles and the pulmonary artery and aorta.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.label: Mitral valve arcade
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.definition: Anomalous mitral valve arcade is diagnosed based on the following features (1) An adequately sized mitral valve orifice; (2) short, thick, and poorly differentiated chordae with direct union of the papillary muscles to the anterior leaflet; (3) narrow or nearly nonexistent spaces between the abnormal chordae; and (4) greater differentiation of the chordae attached to the posterior papillary muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.label: Common atrium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.definition: Complete absence of the interatrial septum with common atrioventricular valve and two atrioventricular connections.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.label: Cor triatriatum dexter
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.definition: A congenital anomaly with partitioning of the right atrium to form a triatrial heart caused by persistence of the right valve of the sinus venosus. Typically, the right atrial partition is due to exaggerated fetal eustachian and thebesian valves, which together form an incomplete septum across the lower part of the atrium. This septum may range from a reticulum to a substantial sheet of tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.label: Sinus venosus atrial septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.definition: An interatrial communication caused by a deficiency of the common wall between the superior vena cava (SVC) and the right-sided pulmonary veins. SVASD is commonly associated with anomalous pulmonary venous connection (APVC) of some or all of the pulmonary veins, which produces additional left-to-right shunting.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.label: Double orifice mitral valve
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.definition: The left atrio-ventricular connection consists of two anatomically distinct orifices separated by accessory fibrous tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.label: Cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001156.definition: Cleft in the anterior mitral valve leaflet not associated with an atrioventricular canal defect.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Parachute mitral valve
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: Abnormality of the mitral valve apparatus, whereby chordae attach to a single papillary muscle or hypoplastic papillary muscles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Supramitral ring
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: A congenital stenotic mitral valvular anomaly with a ring of tissue above the mitral valve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Hypoplastic tricuspid valve
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: Congenital defect characterized by underdevelopment of the tricuspid valve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Imperforate atrioventricular valve
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: An atrioventricular valve that has failed to open (atretic).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Imperforate tricuspid valve
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: A tricuspid valve that has failed to open.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Intermediate atrioventricular canal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: A specific combination of heart defects with a primum atrial septal defect, cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet, and inlet ventricular defect. There is one valve annulus and two valve orifices.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Partial atrioventricular canal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: A specific combination of heart defects including a primum atrial septal defect and cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet. There is not an inlet ventricular septal defect present. There are two valve annuluses and two valve orifices.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Transitional atrioventricular canal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: A specific combination of heart defects with a primum atrial septal defect, cleft anterior mitral valve leaflet, and an inlet ventricular septal defect. There are two valve annuli and two valve orifices.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.label: Unbalanced atrioventricular canal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001157.definition: Anatomic features of unbalanced atrioventricular septal defect (AVSD) include varying amounts of ventricular hypoplasia, as well as malalignment of the atrioventricular junction. In complete AVSD, the common AV valve can be situated either equally over the right and left ventricles (balanced) or unequally over the ventricles (unbalanced).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: Abnormally short chordae tendineae of the mitral valve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Double outlet left ventricle
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: A congenital defect of heart development characterized by origin of both pulmonary artery and aorta from the morphological left ventricle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Abdominal ectopia cordis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: Displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and into the abdomen.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Cervical ectopia cordis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region and without a defect of the sternum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Thoracocervical ectopia cordis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: A type of ectopia cordis with the heart partially in the cervical region with a defect of the superior portion of the sternum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Thoracic ectopia cordis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: Congenital malformation of the thoracic wall with partial or total displacement of the heart outside the thoracic cavity. This feature is associated with sternal cleft or absence of the sternum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Thoracoabdominal ectopia cordis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: Congenital malformation of the ventral wall with partial or total evisceration of the heart outside the thoracic cavity and displacement partially into the abdominal cavity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Abnormal branching pattern of the aortic arch
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: A deviance from the norm of the origin or course of the right brachiocephalic artery, the left common carotid artery, the left subclavian artery or the proximal vertebral arteries.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Cervical aortic arch
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: The aortic arch extends into the soft tissues of the neck before turning down into to become the descending aorta.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.label: Common origin of the right brachiocephalic artery and left common carotid artery
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001158.definition: The left common carotid artery has a common origin with the innominate artery.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.label: Double aortic arch
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.definition: A conenital abnormality of the aortic arch in which the two embryonic aortc arches form a vascular ring that surrounds the trachea or esophagus and then join to form the descending aorta. Double aortic arch can cause symptoms because of compression of the esophagus (dysphagia, cyanosis while eating) or trachea (stridor).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.label: Left aortic arch with cervical origin of the right subclavian artery
Left aortic arch with isolated subclavian artery
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.definition: The subclavian artery arises from ductus arteriosus. While the ductus arteriosus is patent its blood supply comes from the ductus, hence from the pulmonary artery. After it closes, the blood supply is retrogradely from the vertebral artery via the circle of Willis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.label: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.definition: A patent ductus arteriosus or ductal ligament completes the ring.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.label: Right aortic arch with retroesophageal diverticulum of Kommerell
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.definition: Aortic arch crosses the right mainstem bronchus. The left carotid artery is the first branch, right carotid artery the second branch and right subclavian artery as the third branch.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.label: Left aortic arch with retroesophageal right subclavian artery
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.definition: Aortic arch crosses the left mainstem bronchus. The first branch is the right carotid artery, the second branch is the left carotid artery, the third branch is the subclavian artery, the fourth branch is the right subclavian artery arising from the posteromedial aspect of the distal aortic arch and continuing posterior to the esophagus to the right hand side of the body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.label: Left aortic arch with right descending aorta and right ductus arteriosus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.definition: The ring may be completed by the ductal ligament.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.label: Right aortic arch with left descending aorta and left ductus arteriosus
Right aortic arch with retroesophageal left subclavian artery
Mesocardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001159.definition: Mesocardia is an abnormal location of the heart in which the heart is in a midline position and the longitudinal axis of the heart lies in the mid-sagittal plane.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.label: Abnormal direction of ventricular apex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.definition: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex. Left sided is normal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.label: Rightward direction of ventricular apex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.definition: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex towards the right. Left sided is normal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.label: Midline direction of ventricular apex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.definition: Abnormal plane of direction of the heart from the base to the apex in the midline. Left sided is normal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.label: Congenital malformation of the great arteries
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.definition: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the aorta and pulmonary arteries.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.label: Aortopulmonary window
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.definition: A congenital anomaly with an abnormal connection between the aorta and the main pulmonary artery resulting in an aortopulmonary shunt.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.label: Congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.definition: A congenitally corrected transposition of the great arteries with a ventricular septal defect: a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart. The ventricular septal defect is centered around the most superior aspect of the ventricular septum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.label: obsolete Transposition of the great arteries with intact ventricular septum
obsolete Transposition of the great arteries with ventricular septal defect
Type II truncus arteriosus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.definition: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) with each pulmonary artery arising separate from each other on the posterior or lateral aspect of the truncus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.label: Type III truncus arteriosus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001160.definition: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby one of the two pulmonary artery branched does not arise from the common pulmonary trunk, but instead from the ductus arteriosus or directly from the aorta.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Type IV truncus arteriosus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: Truncus arteriosus (single great artery leaving the base of the heart, giving rise to the coronary, pulmonary, and systemic arteries) whereby the aortic arch is hypoplastic or interrupted, and a large patent ductus arteriosus is present.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Interrupted aortic arch
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: Non-continuity of the arch of aorta with an atretic point or absent segment.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Interrupted aortic arch type A
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment at the level of the isthmus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Interrupted aortic arch type B
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment between the left carotid and subclavian arteries.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Interrupted aortic arch type C
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: Non-continuity of the aortic arch with an atretic point or absent segment between the innominate and left carotid arteries.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Abnormal pulmonary situs morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, which is defined by characteristics such as the number of lobes per lung and the relationship of the pulmonary arteries to their bronchi.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Pulmonary situs inversus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: Mirror image arrangement of the mainstem bronchi with the right pulmonary artery posterior to the right upper lobe bronchus and the left pulmonary artery anterior to the left upper lobe bronchus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Pulmonary situs ambiguus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which the morphology of both left and right lungs is the same.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic right lungs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which both lungs have the morphology of a right lung.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.label: Pulmonary situs ambiguus with bilateral morphologic left lungs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001161.definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the morphological right and left lungs, in which both lungs have the morphology of a left lung.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Abnormality of abdominal situs
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: An abnormality of the abdominal situs, i.e., of the sidedness of the abdomen and its organs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Gerbode ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: A type of ventricular septal defect communicating directly between the left ventricle and right atrium. This is anatomically possible because the normal tricuspid valve is more apically displaced than the mitral valve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Inlet ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: A ventricular septal defect that involves the inlet of the right ventricular septum immediately inferior to the AV valve apparatus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Muscular ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: The trabecular septum is the largest part of the interventricular septum. It extends from the membranous septum to the apex and superiorly to the infundibular septum. A defect in the trabecular septum is called muscular VSD if the defect is completely rimmed by muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Apical muscular ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: A muscular ventricular septal defect located at the apex of the heart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Multiple muscular ventricular septal defects
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: A type of muscular ventricular septal defect characterized by the presence of multiple small defects in the ventricular septum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Scimitar anomaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: Right pulmonary venous return to the inferior vena cava.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Aorto-ventricular tunnel
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: Aorto-ventricular tunnel is a congenital, extracardiac channel which connects the ascending aorta above the sinotubular junction to the cavity of the left, or (less commonly) right ventricle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Congenital defect of the pericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: A developmental defect of the pericardium with congenital onset.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.label: Total absence of the pericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001162.definition: No pericardium around the heart, occurring as a congenital defect, not the result of a surgical pericardectomy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Complete diaphragmatic absence of pericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: No pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Complete right sided absence of pericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: No pericardium is present on the righthand side of the heart. It is a congenital absence of pericardium rather than the result of a pericardectomy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Partial right sided absence of pericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: A congenital anomaly with lack of part of the pericardium on the righthand side of the heart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Complete left sided absence of pericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: A congenital anomaly with complete lack of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Partial left sided absence of pericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: A congenital anomaly with lack of part of the pericardium on the lefthand side of the heart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Partial diaphragmatic absence of pericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: Lack of a part of the pericardium over the diaphragmatic surface of the heart. It is a congenital defect, not the result of a pericardectomy. Pericardium is present on other parts of the heart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Abnormal coronary artery origin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: Isolated abnormalities of the coronary artery origins. This may be in associated with other structural heart malformations but not the patterns of complex structural heart malformations which result in abnormal course of the coronary arteries.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Anomalous origin of coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: A coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Anomalous origin of left coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: Left main coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the left cusp of the aortic valve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.label: Anomalous origin of right coronary artery from the pulmonary artery
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001163.definition: Right coronary artery begins (branches off from) the pulmonary artery rather than as normal from the root of the aorta, above the right cusp of the aortic valve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Single coronary artery origin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: The presence of a single coronary artery ostium from which both coronary arteries arise.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Coronary artery fistula
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: A congenital malformation with abnormal connection between one of the coronary arteries and a heart chamber or another blood vessel.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Abnormal coronary sinus morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: An abnormality of the coronary sinus, which is formed by the union of the great cardiac vein and the left marginal vein and terminates in the right atrium. The coronary sinus functions to o collect deoxygenated blood from the myocardium of the heart and drain it into the right atrium.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Coronary sinus atrial septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: An atrial septal defect characterized by a deficiency in the tissue separating the coronary sinus from the left atrium (LA). This results in partial or complete unroofing of the coronary sinus leading to a predominantly left-to-right shunt through the coronary sinus (LA to coronary sinus to right atrium [RA]). The orifice of the ostium is frequently large because of the increased flow. From the RA side, the defect is located at the level of the coronary sinus ostium and may also include some deficiency in atrial tissue around the ostium. From the LA side, the size can be variable depending on the degree of unroofing of the coronary sinus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Coronary sinus diverticulum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: A venous pouch within the left ventricular wall, with a neck opening into the coronary sinus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Dilatation of the sinus of Valsalva
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: Abnormal outpouching or sac-like dilatation of one of the anatomic dilations of the ascending aorta, which occurs just above the aortic valve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Juxtaductal coarctation of the aorta
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized at the insertion of the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the juxtaductal region of aortic arch.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Postductal coarctation of the aorta
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: Narrowing or constriction of the aorta localized distal to the ductus arteriosus, i.e., to the postductal region of aortic arch.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Patent ductus arteriosus after birth at term
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus in postnatal life when birth was at 37 completed weeks of gestation or greater.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.label: Patent ductus arteriosus after premature birth
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001164.definition: Abnormal persistent patency of the ductus arteriosus when birth was at less than 37 weeks completed gestation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Bilateral ductus arteriosus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: The presence of both a left and a right ductus arteriosus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a subaortic ventricular septal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that extends anterosuperiorly and are closely related to the pulmonary artery as well, are considered to be doubly committed. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Double outlet right ventricle with doubly committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a subaortic ventritricular septal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that extends anterosuperiorly and are closely related to the pulmonary artery as well, are considered to be doubly committed. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a non-committed ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a VSD that is anatomically related to, or close to, neither great vessel, being separated from both by considerable muscle, and also has a pulmonary stenosis; abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Double outlet right ventricle with non-committed ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a non-committed ventricular septal defect (VSD), which is a VSD that is anatomically related to, or close to, neither great vessel, being separated from both by considerable muscle, but there is not accompanying pulmonary stenosis; the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the aortic origin. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Double outlet right ventricle with subaortic ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the aortic origin. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect and pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the pulmonary origin. There is associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Double outlet right ventricle with subpulmonary ventricular septal defect without pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: A double outlet right ventricle with a ventricular spetal defect (a hole between the two bottom chambers (ventricles) of the heart), that is considered to be closely related to the pulmonary origin. There is not associated pulmonary stenosis, the abnormal narrowing or constriction of the pulmonary artery, in the main pulmonary artery and/or in the left or right pulmonary artery branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.label: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent pulmonary valve
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001165.definition: Features of tetralogy of Fallot with either rudimentary ridges or the complete absence of pulmonic valve tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.label: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.definition: Anomalous origin of one pulmonary artery from the ascending aorta with the contralateral pulmonary artery arising from the right ventricle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.label: Anomalous origin of left pulmonary artery from ascending aorta
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.definition: The left pulmonary artery originates from the ascending aorta in the presence of a pulmonary valve and main pulmonary artery.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.label: Tricuspid atresia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.definition: Failure to develop of the tricuspid valve and thus lack of the normal connection between the right atrium and the right ventricle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.label: Right ventricular cardiomyopathy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.definition: Right ventricular dysfunction (global or regional) with functional and morphological right ventricular abnormalities, with or without left ventricular disease.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.label: Left ventricular noncompaction cardiomyopathy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.definition: Left ventricular non-compaction (LVNC) is characterized by prominent left ventricular trabeculae and deep inter-trabecular recesses. The myocardial wall is often thickened with a thin, compacted epicardial layer and a thickened endocardial layer. In some patients, LVNC is associated with left ventricular dilatation and systolic dysfunction, which can be transient in neonates.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.label: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.definition: Transient left ventricular apical ballooning syndrome or takotsubo cardiomyopathy is characterized by transient regional systolic dysfunction involving the left ventricular apex and/or mid-ventricle in the absence of obstructive coronary disease on coronary angiography. Patients present with an abrupt onset of angina-like chest pain, and have diffuse T-wave inversion, sometimes preceded by ST-segment elevation, and mild cardiac enzyme elevation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.label: Absent right superior vena cava
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.definition: Absence of the right superior vena cava (RSVC). An absent RSVC is always associated with a persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC). During normal fetal development, the left-sided anterior venous cardinal system regresses, leaving the coronary sinus (CS) and the ligament of Marshall. Failure of the closure of the left anterior cardinal vein results in PLSVC. In general, PLSVC is associated with the right superior vena cava (RSVC) and drains into the RA via a dilated CS. When developmental arrest occurs at an earlier stage, the CS is absent and the PLSVC drains into the left atrium.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.label: Bilateral superior vena cava with bridging vein
Bilateral superior vena cava with no bridging vein
Left superior vena cava draining directly to the left atrium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001166.definition: A persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) that drains into the left atrium instead of the right atrium via the coronary sinus, resulting in a right to left sided shunt.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.label: Left superior vena cava draining to coronary sinus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.definition: A persistent left superior vena cava (PLSVC) that drains into the right atrium via the coronary sinus. This is the case in 80-92% of cases of PLSVC and results in no hemodynamic consequence.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.label: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.definition: Interrupted inferior vena cava with azygous continuation is the result of connection failure between the right subcardinal vein and the right vitelline vein. Consequently, venous blood from the caudal part of the body reaches the heart via the azygous vein and superior vena cava.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.label: Cardiac myxoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.definition: A myxoma (tumor of primitive connective tissue) of the heart. Cardiac myxomas consist of stellate to plump, cytologically bland mesenchymal cells set in a myxoid stroma. Cardiac myxomas are of endocardial origin and general project from the endocardium into a cardiac chamber.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.label: Cardiac hemangioma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.definition: Abnormal proliferation of blood vessels within the cardiac cavities attached to the endocardium.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.label: Cardiac teratoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.definition: A teratoma within the heart. Most commonly, these tumors are detected in the pericardial cavity attached to the pulmonary artery and aorta. The tumor size within the heart varies from 2 to 9 cm in diameter, and intrapericardial tumors as large as 15 cm have been reported. Intracardiac tumors arise from the atrial or ventricular wall as nodular masses protruding into the cardiac chambers. Cardiac and pericardial teratomas are easily detected in the fetus and neonate by two-dimensional echocardiography as heterogeneous and encapsulated cystic masses. Histologically, cardiac teratomas contain multiple immature elements including epithelium, neuroglial tissue, thyroid, pancreas, smooth and skeletal muscle, cartilage and bone.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.label: Arrhythmia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.definition: Any cardiac rhythm other than the normal sinus rhythm. Such a rhythm may be either of sinus or ectopic origin and either regular or irregular. An arrhythmia may be due to a disturbance in impulse formation or conduction or both.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.label: Tetralogy of Fallot with absent subarterial conus
Tetralogy of Fallot with atrioventricular canal defect
Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia and major aortopulmonary collateral arteries
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.definition: A type of tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary atresia in which all pulmonary blood flow is derived from major aortopulmonary collateral arteries (MAPCA).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.label: Tetralogy of Fallot with pulmonary stenosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001167.definition: The commonest form of tetralogy of Fallot characterized by pulmonary stenosis, overriding aorta, ventricular septum defect, and right ventricular hypertrophy, without pulmonary atresia, absent pulmonary valve, atrioventricular canal defect or absent subarterial conus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: Subarterial ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: A ventricular septal defect that lies beneath the semilunar valve(s) in the conal or outlet septum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: Perimembranous ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: A ventricular septal defect that is confluent with and involves the membranous septum and is bordered by an atrioventricular valve, not including the type 3 VSDs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: Restrictive ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that is small enough to restrict flow across it such that a pressure gradient exists between the two sides of the VSD.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: Non-restrictive ventricular septal defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: Any ventricular septal defect (VSD) that does not restrict flow across it sufficiently to generate a pressure gradient between the two sides of the VSD.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: Infra-aortic superior vena cava
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: The superior vena cava passes below the aortic arch.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: Abnormal coronary artery course
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: An abnormal path of a coronary artery.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: AV nodal tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: A type of supraventricular tachycardia that originates in the atrioventricular node.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: Supraventricular tachycardia in which an accessory pathway connecting the atria and ventricles, apart from the AV node, participates as a necessary part of a reentrant mechanism.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory connection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001168.definition: Supraventricular tachycardia with an accessory connection mediated pathway that is called concealed becasue it is not seen on the ECG during sinus rhythm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001169.label: Permanent junctional reciprocating tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001169.definition: An incessant orthodromic tachycardia with anterograde conduction over the atrioventricular node and by retrograde conduction via an accessory pathway usually located in the posteroseptal region with slow and decremental conduction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001169.label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the left free wall
Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the right free wall
Supraventricular tachycardia with a concealed accessory pathway on the septum
Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway
Cerebellar hemorrhage
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001169.definition: Hemorrhage into the parenchyma of the cerebellum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001169.label: Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the left free wall
Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the right free wall
Supraventricular tachycardia with a manifest accessory pathway on the septum

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Automatic atrial tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: Chronic supraventricular tachycardia predominantly seen in childhood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Multifocal atrial tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: Multifocal atrial tachycardia is a rare supraventricular arrhythmia in neonates and young infants that is characterized by multiple P waves with varying P wave morphology and is usually asymptomatic.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Abnormal electrophysiology of sinoatrial node origin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: An abnormality of the sinoatrial (SA) node in the right atrium. THe SA node acts as the pacemaker of the heart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Sinus tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: Heart rate of greater than 100 beats per minute.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Sick sinus syndrome
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: An abnormality involving the generation of the action potential by the sinus node and is characterized by an atrial rate inappropriate for physiological requirements. Manifestations include severe sinus bradycardia, sinus pauses or arrest, sinus node exit block, chronic atrial tachyarrhythmias, alternating periods of atrial bradyarrhythmias and tachyarrhythmias, and inappropriate responses of heart rate during exercise or stress.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: First degree atrioventricular block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: Delay of conduction through the atrioventricular node, which is manifested as prolongation of the PR interval in the electrocardiogram (EKG). All atrial impulses reach the ventricles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Second degree atrioventricular block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: An intermittent atrioventricular block with failure of some atrial impulses to conduct to the ventricles, i.e., some but not all atrial impulses are conducted through the atrioventricular node and trigger ventricular contraction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Mobitz I atrioventricular block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: Progressive PR interval prolongation with the subsequent occurrence of a single nonconducted P wave that results in a pause. The pause that follows the nonconducted impulse is less than fully compensatory (less than the sum of two normal sinus intervals).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Mobitz II atrioventricular block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: A type of second degree atrioventricular (AV) block characterized by sudden failure to conduct an impulse through the AV node without a preceding change in the PR interval.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.label: Atrioventricular dissociation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001170.definition: Atrioventricular (AV) dissociation is present if the atria and the ventricles are under the control of two separate pacemakers. AV dissociation can occur in the absence of a primary AV conduction disturbance.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Bundle branch block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: Block of conduction of electrical impulses along the Bundle of His or along one of its bundle branches.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Left anterior fascicular block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: Conduction block in the anterior division of the left bundle branch of the bundle of His.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Right bundle branch block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: A conduction block of the right branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a prolongation of the QRS complex (greater than 0.12 s) with delayed activation of the right ventricle and terminal delay on the EKG.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Left bundle branch block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: A conduction block of the left branch of the bundle of His. This manifests as a generalized disturbance of QRS morphology on EKG.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Libman-Sacks lesions
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: Libman-Sacks valvular lesions are sterile fibrofibrinous vegetations that favor the left-sided heart valves and usually form on the ventricular surface of the mitral valve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Trifascicular block
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: Abnormal conduction in all three divisions of the intraventricular conducting tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Junctional ectopic tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: Junctional ectopic tachycardia (JET) is a unique type of supraventricular arrhythmia defined by narrow QRS complex and atrioventricular (AV) dissociation or retrograde atrial conduction in a 1:1 pattern.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: Accessory pathway-related atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) involves an abnormal electrical conduction of the accessory pathway. The accessory pathway connecting impulses between the atrium and the ventricle can be seen at any site in the AV groove.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Abnormality of the pulmonary veins
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: An abnormality of the pulmonary veins.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.label: Supracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001171.definition: Type 1 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.label: Cardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.definition: Type 2 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.label: Infracardiac total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.definition: Type 3 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.label: Mixed total anomalous pulmonary venous connection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.definition: Type 4 total anomalous pulmonary venous connection.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.label: Congenital malformation of the right heart
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.definition: Defect or defects of the morphogenesis of the right heart identifiable at birth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.label: Uhl's anomaly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.definition: Uhl anomaly of the right ventricle refers to the almost complete absence of right ventricular myocardium, normal tricuspid valve, and preserved septal and left ventricular myocardium.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.label: Persistent fetal circulation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.definition: Systemic desaturation of a liveborn baby resulting from persistent pulmonary hypertension with a patent ductus arteriosus and patent foramen ovale, such that the circulation in postnatal life follows the fetal course.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.label: Elbow clonus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.definition: Clonus at the elbow joint, i.e., an exaggerated phasic stretch reflex characterized by repetitive, rhythmic contractions at the elbow, generated by rapid passive stretch at the elbow joint.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.label: Abnormality of joint mobility
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001172.definition: An abnormality in the range and ease of motion of joints across their normal range.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Abnormal central sensory function
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: An abnormality of sensation related to CNS function. Assuming the primary sensory modalities are intact and the patient is alert and cooperative, the presence of an abnormality of sensory function may indicate a lesion of a parietal cortex, the thalamocortical projections to the parietal cortex, or the spinal cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Abnormality of circulating cortisol level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: An abnormality of the concentration of cortisol in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Abnormal adrenal morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: Any structural anomaly of the adrenal glands.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Abnormality of adrenal physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: A functional abnormality of the adrenal glands.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Central adrenal insufficiency
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: A form of adrenal insufficiency related to a lack of ACTH, which leads to a decrease in the production of cortisol by the adrenal glands. Aldosterone production is not usually affected.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Adrenocorticotropin deficient adrenal insufficiency
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in ACTH production.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Primary hyperaldosteronism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by a defect within the adrenal gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Corticotropin-releasing hormone deficient adrenal insufficiency
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in corticotropin-releasing hormone production.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor defect
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: Adrenal insufficiency secondary to a defect in the corticotropin-releasing hormone receptor.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.label: Dexamethasone-suppressible primary hyperaldosteronism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001173.definition: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone can be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Glucocortocoid-insensitive primary hyperaldosteronism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: A form of primary hyperaldosteronism in which the overproduction of aldosterone cannot be suppressed by the administration of dexamethasone or similar glucocorticoids.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Secondary hyperaldosteronism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: A form of hyperaldosteronism caused by abnormally increased renin levels.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Ectopic adrenal gland
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: Abnormal anatomical location of the adrenal gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Adrenal gland agenesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: Absent development of the adrenal gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Secondary hypercortisolism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: Hypercortisolemia associated with a overproduction of ACTH (often from a tumor), leading secondarily to overproduction of cortisol.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Non-secretory adrenocortical adenoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: An hormonally inactive adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that does not secrete excessive amounts of adrenal hormones.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Secretory adrenocortical adenoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: An hormonally active adrenocortical adenoma, that is, an adenoma that secretes excessive amounts of adrenal hormones.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Abnormality of the anterior pituitary
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: An abnormality of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Adrenocorticotropic hormone deficiency
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: A reduced ability to secrete adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), a hormone that stimulates the adrenal cortex to secrete of glucocorticoids such as cortisol.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.label: Adrenocorticotropic hormone excess
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001174.definition: Overproduction of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), which generally leads secondarily to overproduction of cortisol by the adrenal cortex.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.label: Neoplasm of the anterior pituitary
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.definition: A tumor (abnormal growth of tissue) of the adenohypophysis, which is also known as the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.label: Abnormal posterior pituitary morphogenesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.definition: An abnormality of the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.label: Neoplasm of the posterior pituitary
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.definition: The presence of a neoplasm (tumor) in the neurohypophysis, which is also known as the posterior lobe of the hypophysis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.label: Posterior pituitary dysgenesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.definition: Abnormal development of the neurohypophysis during embryonic growth and development.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.label: Pituicytoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.definition: A solid, low grade, spindle cell, glial neoplasm of adults that originates in the neurohypophysis or infundibulum. Clinical signs and symptoms include visual disturbance, headache and features of hypopituitarism. Pituicytomas are well-circumscribed, solid masses that can measure up to several centimeters. Histologically, they show a compact architecture consisting of elongate, bipolar spindle cells arranged in interlacing fascicles or assuming a storiform pattern.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.label: Ectopic posterior pituitary
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.definition: An abnormal anatomical location of the posterior lobe of the hypophysis, also known as the neurohypophysis. The posterior pituitary is normally present in the dorsal portion of the sella turcica, but when ectopic is usually near the median eminence. This defect is likely to be due to abnormal migration during embryogenesis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.label: Posterior pituitary agenesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.definition: Absence of the neurohypophysis owing to a developmental defect.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.label: Pituitary gonadotropic cell adenoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001175.definition: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces gonadotropins.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Pituitary growth hormone cell adenoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces growth hormone.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Pituitary null cell adenoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: A type of pituitary adenoma that is of unknown cellular origin and that lacks immunocytochemical or fine structural markers. Null cell adenomas are not associated with hormone excess.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Pituitary thyrotropic cell adenoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: A type of pituitary adenoma that produces thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Pituitary carcinoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: A pituitary tumor with subarachnoid, brain, or systemic metastasis. The diagnosis of a pituitary carcinoma requires evidence of metastatic disease, either outside the central nervous system (CNS) or as separate noncontiguous foci within the CNS.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Pituitary spindle cell oncocytoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: A spindled-to-epithelioid, oncocytic, nonendocrine neoplasm of the anterior hypophysis that manifests in adults and follows a benign clinical course. Pituitary spindle cell oncocytomas are firm, fibrous, and adherent to surrounding structures and are highly vascular.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Abnormal parathyroid morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: A structural abnormality of the parathyroid gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Abnormality of the parathyroid physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: A functional abnormality of the parathyroid gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Parathyroid dysgenesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: Abnormal embryonic development of the parathyroid gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.label: Ectopic parathyroid
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001176.definition: An abnormal anatomical location of the parathyroid gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001177.label: Tertiary hyperparathyroidism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001177.definition: A type of hyperparathyroidism that occurs following kidney transplantation, which is a treatment for secondary hyperparathyroidism. Although kidney transplantation leads to a normalization of serum calcium and parathyroid hormone in most patients. The state of persistent hypercalcemia and hyperparathyroidism is referred to as tertiary hyperparathyroidism.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001177.label: Autoimmune hypoparathyroidism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001177.definition: A type of hypoparathyroidism with circulating antiparathyroid or anti-calcium sensing receptor antibodies indicative of autoimmunity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001177.label: Abnormal thyroid morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001177.definition: A structural abnormality of the thyroid gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001177.label: Uninodular goiter
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001177.definition: Enlargement of the thyroid gland related to a singular nodule in the thyroid gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.label: Thyroid hemiagenesis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.definition: Absence of a lobe of the thyroid gland related to a failure of its embryologic development.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.label: Thyroid C cell hyperplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.definition: An abnormal growth of parafollicular (C-cells) cells.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.label: Thyrotoxicosis with toxic single thyroid nodule
Central hypothyroidism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.definition: A type of hypothyroidism due to an insufficient stimulation of an otherwise normal thyroid gland. Central hypothyroidism is caused by either pituitary (secondary hypothyroidism) or hypothalamic (tertiary hypothyroidism) defects.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.label: Increased circulating free T3
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.definition: An elevated concentration of free 3,3',5-triiodo-L-thyronine in the blood circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.label: Impaired sensitivity to thyroid stimulating hormone
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001178.definition: Reduced sensitivity of thyroid follicle cells to stimulation by biologically active thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.label: Neoplasm by histology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.definition: Neoplasm categorized according to type of histological abnormality.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.label: Neoplasm by anatomical site
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.definition: Neoplasm categorized according to the anatomical site of origin of the neoplasm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.label: Embryonal renal neoplasm
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.definition: The presence of an embryonal neoplasm of the kidney that primarily affects children.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.label: Intralobar nephroblastomatosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.definition: Presence of persistent islands of renal blastema in the postnatal kidney, anywhere within a renal lobe (a portion of a kidney consisting of a renal pyramid and the renal cortex above it).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.label: Perilobar nephroblastomatosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.definition: Abnormally persistent foci of embryonal immature blastema located in the superficial cortical region (perilobar).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.label: Papillary renal cell carcinoma type 1
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.definition: A type of papillary renal cell carcinoma that is characterized by small cuboidal cells covering thin papillae with a single line of uniform nuclei and small nucleoli.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.label: Renal oncocytoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001179.definition: A renal tumor originating from an oncocyte, which is an epithelial cell characterized by an excessive amount of mitochondria, resulting in an abundant acidophilic, granular cytoplasm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Midface retrusion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: Posterior positions and/or vertical shortening of the infraorbital and perialar regions, or increased concavity of the face and/or reduced nasolabial angle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Enlargement of parotid gland
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: Increased size of the parotid gland.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Hamartoma of tongue
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: A benign (noncancerous) tumorlike malformation made up of an abnormal mixture of cells and tissues that originates in the tongue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Bifid nose
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: Visually assessable vertical indentation, cleft, or depression of the nasal bridge, ridge and tip.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Abnormal muscle physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: A functional abnormality of a skeletal muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Abnormal skeletal muscle morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: A structural abnormality of a skeletal muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Type 1 muscle fiber atrophy
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: Atrophy (wasting) affecting primary type 1 muscle fibers. This feature in general can only be observed on muscle biopsy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Decreased patellar reflex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: Decreased intensity of the patellar reflex (also known as the knee jerk reflex).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.label: Paradoxical myotonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001180.definition: A type of myotonia that worsens with repeated muscle contractions.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Impaired two-point discrimination
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: A reduced ability to distinguish tactile sensations at points that are very close to one another. This can be tested by using special calipers whose points can be set from 2mm to several centimeters apart.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Impaired touch localization
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: A reduced ability to identify precisely the site of a touch. This test is usually carried out by asking a patient, whose eyes are closed or covered, to touch the same site with a fingertip.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Agraphesthesia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: Impaired ability to recognize letters or numbers drawn by an examiner's fingertip on the patient's skin (the patients eyes are closed or covered throughout this examination).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Increased cerebral lipofuscin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: Lipofuscin (age pigment) is a brown-yellow, electron-dense, autofluorescent material that accumulates progressively over time in lysosomes of postmitotic cells, such as neurons and cardiac myocytes. This term pertains if there is an increase in the accumulation of lipofuscin (also known as autofluorescent lipoprotein) more than expected for the age of the patient.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Increased urinary hypoxanthine level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: The concentration of hypoxanthine in the urine, normalized for urine concentration, is above the upper limit of normal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Cephalocele
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: A congenital defect in the skull, whereby there is a protrusion of part of the cranial contents through a congenital defect in the cranium, usually covered with skin or mucous membrane. The term encephalocele refers to a subclass of these lesions in which brain tissue protrudes through the defect.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Parietal encephalocele
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: An encephalocele located between bregma and lambda.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Basal encephalocele
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: Basal encephalocele is an encephalocele that occurs along the cribriform plate or through the sphenoid bone. The mass may appear in the nasal cavity, nasopharynx, epipharynx, sphenoid sinus, posterior orbit, or pterygopalatine fossa. The important distinction from other types is that no external tumor is visible except in those rare instances of herniations so large that they protrude through the mouth or nares.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.label: Submucous cleft soft palate
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001181.definition: A cleft of the muscular (soft) portion of the palate that is covered by mucous membrane. Soft-palate submucous clefts are characterized by a midline deficiency or lack of muscle tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Membranous choanal atresia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: Absence of the normal opening of the choana (the posterior nasal aperture) as a result of an obstructing choanal membrane that may be thin and strandlike or thick and pluglike.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Abnormal facial skeleton morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: An abnormality of one or more of the set of bones that make up the facial skeleton.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Broad chin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: Increased width of the midpoint of the mandible (mental protuberance) and overlying soft tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Chin with horizontal crease
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: Horizontal crease or fold situated below the vermilion border of the lower lip and above the fatty pad of the chin, with the face at rest.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Chin with H-shaped crease
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: H-shaped crease in the fat pad of the chin.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Tented philtrum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: Prominence of a triangular soft tissue area of the philtrum with the apex to the columella.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Philtrum with midline raphe
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: Narrow ridge in the midline of the philtral groove.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Malaligned philtral ridges
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: Absence of the usual parallel position of philtral ridges.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Midline sinus of philtrum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: Pit in the midline of the philtral groove.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.label: Narrow philtrum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001182.definition: Distance between the philtral ridges, measured just above the vermilion border, more than 2 standard deviations below the mean. Alternatively, an apparently decreased distance between the ridges of the philtrum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.label: Deviated nasal tip
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.definition: Nasal tip positioned to one side of the midline.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.label: Narrow nasal tip
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.definition: Decrease in width of the nasal tip.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.label: Overhanging nasal tip
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.definition: Positioning of the nasal tip inferior to the nasal base.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.label: Moyamoya phenomenon
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.definition: A noninflammatory, progressive occlusion of the intracranial carotid arteries owing to the formation of netlike collateral arteries arising from the circle of Willis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.label: Delayed talus ossification
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.definition: Delayed maturation and calcification of the talus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.label: Partial IgA deficiency
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.definition: Detectable but decreased IgA levels that are more than 2 standard deviations below normal age-adjusted means.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.label: Sclerodactyly
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.definition: Localized thickening and tightness of the skin of the fingers or toes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.label: Abnormal T cell count
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001183.definition: A deviation from the normal count of T cells.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Abnormality of T cell physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: A functional anomaly of T cells.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Ventricular flutter
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: A potentially lethal cardiac arrhythmia characterized by an extremely rapid, hemodynamically unstable ventricular tachycardia (150-300 beats/min) with a large oscillating sine-wave appearance.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Abnormal skeletal morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: An abnormality of the form, structure, or size of the skeletal system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Abnormal musculoskeletal physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: An abnormality of the function of the skeletal system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Abnormal appendicular skeleton morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: An abnormality of the appendicular skeletal system, consisting of the of the limbs, shoulder and pelvic girdles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Osteoblastoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: A benign, painful, tumor of bone characterized by the formation of osteoid tissue, primitive bone and calcified tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Giant cell tumor of bone
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: A bone tumor composed of cellular spindle-cell stroma containing scattered multinucleated giant cells resembling osteoclasts.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Abdominal colic
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: A type of abdominal pain that comes and goes in waves, most often starting and ending suddenly and being of severe intensity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.label: Abnormal bone ossification
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001184.definition: Any anomaly in the formation of bone or of a bony substance, or the conversion of fibrous tissue or of cartilage into bone or a bony substance.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Hemopericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: Accumulation of blood within the pericardial sac.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Chylopericardium
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: Accumulation of chyle (the whitish fluid taken up by the lacteals in the intestine, consisting of an emulsion of lymph and triglyceride fat thatpasses into the veins by the thoracic duct) in the pericardium. Chylopericardium is generally caused by obstruction of or trauma to the thoracic duct.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Serous pericardial effusion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: Accumulation of serous fluid (pale yellow and transparent fluid) in the pericardial sac.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Hemoperitoneum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: Accumulation of blood in the peritoneal cavity owing to internal hemorrhage.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Pharyngeal edema
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: Abnormal accumulation of fluid leading to swelling of the pharynx.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Pica
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: An appetite for and the persistent ingestion of non-food substances such as clay. In order to diagnose pica, this behavior must have persisted over a period of at least one month.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Plasmacytoma
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: A discrete mass of neoplastic monoclonal plasma cells either in the bone marrow or in an extramedullary location.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Reduced factor IX activity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: Decreased activity of coagulation factor IX. Factor IX, which itself is activated by factor Xa or factor VIIa to form factor IXa, activates factor X into factor Xa.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.label: Punctate keratitis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001185.definition: A type of keratitis characterized by inflammation in pinpoint areas of the corneal epithelium.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.label: Metaphyseal dappling
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.definition: The presence of spots or rounded patches of abnormally increased density of metaphyseal bone.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.label: Bilateral trilobed lung
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.definition: Both lungs have three lobes. Normally, the left lung has two lobes, whereas the right lung has three lobes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.label: Abnormal bone collagen fibril morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.definition: Any structural anomaly of the connective tissue bundles in the extracellular matrix of bone tissue that are composed of collagen, and play a role in tissue strength and elasticity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.label: Abnormal sternal ossification
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.definition: Any anomaly in the formation of the bony substance of the sternum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.label: Elevated plasma pyrophosphate
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.definition: An abnormally increased diphosphate(4-) concentration in the blood. Diphosphate(4-), as ester with two phosphate groups, is also known as pyrophosphate.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.label: Abnormal iliac wing morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.definition: An anomaly of the ilium ala. This is the large expanded portion of the ilum which bounds the greater pelvis laterally.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.label: Sciatica
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.definition: Pain in the lower back and hip radiating in the distribution of the sciatic nerve.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.label: Abnormal platelet function
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001186.definition: Any anomaly in the function of thrombocytes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Impaired arachidonic acid-induced platelet aggregation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.definition: Abnormal response to arachidonic acid as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of arachidonic acid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Impaired ristocetin-induced platelet aggregation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.definition: Abnormal response to ristocetin as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of ristocetin.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Impaired thrombin-induced platelet aggregation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.definition: Abnormal response to thrombin or thrombin mimetics as manifested by reduced or lacking aggregation of platelets upon addition of thrombin (or thrombin mimetics).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Abnormal platelet count
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.definition: Abnormal number of platelets per volume of blood. In a healthy adult, a normal platelet count is between 150,000 and 450,000 per microliter of blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.definition: Low platelet count following administration of unfractionated or (less commonly) low-molecular weight heparin.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Abnormal platelet morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.definition: An anomaly in platelet form, ultrastructure, or intracellular organelles.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Abnormal platelet volume
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.definition: Anomalous size of platelets. Most normal sized platelets are 1.5 to 3 micrometers in diameter. Large platelets are 4 to 7 micrometers. Giant platelets are larger than 7 micrometers and usually 10 to 20 micrometers.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Increased mean platelet volume
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.definition: Average platelet volume above the upper limit of the normal reference interval.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_001187.label: Abnormal platelet membrane protein expression
