http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.label: Midsystolic murmur
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.definition: A systolic murmur that begins after S1 and ends before S2, typically with a crescendo-decrescendo pattern.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.label: Late systolic murmur
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.definition: A murmur that occurs in the latter phase of systole.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.label: Holosystolic murmur
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.definition: A heart murmur that occurs during the entire systolic phase from S1 to S2.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.label: Diastolic heart murmur
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.definition: A heart murmur that occurs during diastole, i.e., in the time between S2 and the subsequent S1.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.label: Middiastolic murmur
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003166.definition: A murmur that occurs in the middle of the diastolic phase.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Continuous heart murmur
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: A murmur that occurs in both systole and diastole.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Typical atrial flutter
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: Typical atrial flutter is an organised atrial tachycardia. It can also be defined as a macroreentrant tachycardia confined to the right atrium. This arrhythmia has a 200-260 ms cycle length, although it may fluctuate depending on patient's previous treatment or ablation, congenital heart disease, etc. Ventricular rate response will be limited by the atrioventricular node conductions, usually presenting a 2:1 or 3:1 response, during atrial flutter. Typical (counter clockwise) flutter is associated with the common flutter pattern: a regular continuous undulation with dominant negative deflections in inferior leads II, III and aVF, often described also as a saw tooth pattern, and flat atrial deflections in leads I and aVL. Atrial deflections in V1 can be positive, biphasic or negative.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Reverse typical atrial flutter
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: A type of atrial flutter associated with rounded or bimodal positive deflections in inferior leads II, III and aVF, and a very characteristic bimodal negative wave in the shape of a W is seen in lead V1.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Orthodromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: A type of atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) where the atrioventricular node is used for anterograde conduction and the accessory pathway for retrograde conduction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Antidromic atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: A type of atrioventricular reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) where the accessory pathway is used for anterograde conduction and the atrioventricular node for retrograde conduction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Fascicular left ventricular tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: A ventricular tachycardia (VT) characterized by right bundle branch block (RBBB) and left axis deviation (LAD) on electrocardiogram (ECG).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Monomorphic ventricular tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: A type of ventricular tachycardia that is characterized by uniform QRS complexes within each lead (i.e., each QRS is identical or nearly so).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: A type of ventricular tachycardia that is characterized by variable QRS complexes within each lead (i.e., QRS complexes may be different from beat to beat).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Atherosclerotic lesion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: A lesion associated with atherosclerosis, a multifactorial and multipart progressive disease manifested by the focal development within the arterial wall of lesions, that ranges from teh development of a fatty streak, plaque progression, and plaque disruption. Atherosclerotic lesions demonstrate consistent morphological characteristics, which indicate that each type may stabilize temporarily or permanently and that progression to the next type may require an additional stimulus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.label: Type I atherosclerotic lesion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003167.definition: Type I lesions represent the very initial changes and are recognized as an increase in the number of intimal macrophages and the appearance of macrophages filled with lipid droplets (foam cells).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Type II atherosclerotic lesion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: Type II atherosclerotic lesions include the fatty streak lesion, the first grossly visible lesion, and are characterized by layers of macrophage foam cells and lipid droplets within intimal smooth muscle cells and minimal coarse-grained particles and heterogeneous droplets of extracellular lipid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Type III atherosclerotic lesion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: Type III (intermediate) atherosclerotic lesions are the morphological and chemical bridge between type II and advanced lesions. Type III lesions appear in some adaptive intimal thickenings (progression-prone locations) in young adults and are characterized by pools of extracellular lipid in addition to all the components of type II lesions.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Type V atherosclerotic lesion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: Type V lesions are defined as lesions in which prominent new fibrous connective tissue has formed. When the new tissue is part of a lesion with a lipid core (type IV), this type of morphology may be referred to as fibroatheroma or type Va lesion. A type V lesion in which the lipid core and other parts of the lesion are calcified may be referred to as type Vb. A type V lesion in which a lipid core is absent and lipid in general is minimal may be referred to as type Vc. With these lesions, arteries are variously narrowed, generally more than with type IV. Importantly, as with type IV lesions, type V lesions may develop fissures, hematoma, and/or thrombus (type VI lesion), and for this reason too they are clinically relevant.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Type VI atherosclerotic lesion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: Type VI atherosclerotic lesions generally have the underlying morphology of type IV or V lesions, surface disruptions, hematoma, and thrombosis may be (although less often) superimposed on any other type of lesion and even on intima without an apparent lesion. Complicating features may arise because of individual differences in risk factors and tissue reactions. These may include differences in composition of the blood, the relative quantities and distributions in the components of the underlying lesion or intima, as well as modifications of shear and tensile forces to which the lesion or intima is exposed. Clinical imaging of lesions may be expected to contribute greatly to the understanding of type VI lesions and the associated clinical syndromes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Renal artery atherosclerosis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: An atherosclerotic lesion located in the renal artery.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Abnormal stool composition
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: Abnormal level of metabolite or other abnormal analyte result in a stool test.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Increased stool alpha1-antitrypsin concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: An abnormally elevated amount of alpha1-antitrypsin in the feces.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Abnormally loud pulmonic component of the second heart sound
Erythroid dysplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: Dysplasia in the erythroid lineage, which presents with a variety of morphological changes in the bone marrow, including nuclear budding or irregular nuclear contour in erythroblasts.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.label: Megakaryocyte dysplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003168.definition: The presence of micro-megakaryocytes, hypo-lobed, or non-lobed nuclei in megakaryocytes of all sizes and multiple, widely-separated nuclei.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.label: Opportunistic infection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.definition: An infection that is caused by a pathogen that would generally not be able to cause an infection in a host with a normal immune system. Such pathogens take advantage of the opportunity, so to speak, that is provided by a weakened immune system.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.label: Severe cytomegalovirus infection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.definition: An unusually severe infection by cytomegalovirus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.label: Severe Epstein Barr virus infection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.definition: An unusually severe Epstein Barr virus (EBV) infection.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.label: Severe parainfluenza infection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.definition: An unusually severe infection by a parainfluenza virus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.label: Disseminated viral infection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.definition: A viral infection that fails to be contained by the immune sytem and spreads throughout the body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.label: Disseminated infection with live vaccine virus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.definition: A dissemination viral infection caused by a live attenuated vaccine virus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.label: obsolete Disseminated Bacillus Calmette-Guerin infection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.definition: Failure to contain thebacillus Calmette-Guerin (BCG) following vaccination leading to spread of BCG to many sites in the body. The tuberculosis vaccine BCG contains live attenuated Mycobacterium bovis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.label: Disseminated cryptosporidium infection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003169.definition: Failure to contain infection by a protozoan of the genus Cryptosporidium, leading to spread to many parts of the body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Invasive parasitic infection
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: A parasitic infection whereby the parasite invades (migrates through) tissues of the infected host.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Anterior chamber inflammatory cells
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: The presence of inflammatory cells in the aqueous humor of the anterior chamber of the eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Anterior chamber red blood cells
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: The presence of erythrocyte in the aqueous humor of the anterior chamber of the eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Abnormal ear morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: Any structural anomaly of the ear.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Abnormal ear physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: Any functional anomaly of the ear.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Compensatory head posture
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: A compensatory head posture occurs when the head is deviated out of the normal primary straight head position in order to compensate for an ocular problem.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Compensatory chin depression
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: A tendency to hold the chin depressed (lowered) to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Compensatory face turn to the right
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: A tendency to turn the face to the right to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Compensatory face turn to the left
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: A tendency to turn the face to the left to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.label: Compensatory head tilt to the right shoulder
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003170.definition: A tendency to tilt the head towards the right shoulder to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: Compensatory head tilt to the left shoulder
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: A tendency to tilt the head towards the left shoulder to compensate for a limitation of eye movement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: Asymmetric abdominal aortic aneurysm
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: An abdominal aortic aneurysm that is not symmetric around its axis (not axisymmetric).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: Constant exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: A form of divergent strabismus (exotropia) in which the eye turns outward at all distances and at all times.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: Distance exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: A type of divergent strabismus (exotropia) in which an eye tends to turn outwards (i.e., the eye squints) mainly when looking at distant objects. The eyes tend to remain straight when they look at near objects. Distance exotropia may be constant or intermittent.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: Near exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: An intermittent exotropia where there is binocular single vision on distance fixation and exotropia at near (intermittent or constant).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: Cyclic exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: A type of exotropia (divergent strabismus) in which binocular single vision alternates with large angle exotropia in rhythmic cycle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: Alternating exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: A type of exotropia in which either eye may be used for fixation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: Consecutive exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: Exotropia in an individual who has previously had esotropia or esophoria.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.label: True distance exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003171.definition: Exotropia (intermittent or constant) on distance fixation with binocular single vision on near fixation under all testing conditions. The accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC:A) ratio is within normal limits.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Simulated distance exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: Exotropia (intermittent or constant) worse for distance fixation in which the near angle of deviation increases (or near exophoria becomes exotropia) with: (1) prolonged disruption of fusion and/or (2) elimination of accommodation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Sensory exotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: A type of divergent strabismus (exotropia) that develops in a poorly seeing eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Near esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: An intermittent esotropia where there is binocular single vision on distance fixation and esotropia at near even when the accommodation is relieved.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Secondary esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: Convergent squint which follows loss or impairment of vision.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Microtropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: A small angle heterotropia (usually of 10 diopters or less) in which a form of binocular single vision occurs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Hypophoria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: A form of latent strabismus (heterophoria) in which, on dissociation, the occluded eye deviates downwards.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Incyclotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: A type of cyclotropia (torsion of one or both eye around the visual axis of the eyes) in which the upper poles of the globes are rotated inward (medially) to each other.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Excyclotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: A type of cyclotropia (torsion of one or both eye around the visual axis of the eyes) in which the upper poles of the globes are rotated outward (laterally) to each other.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Mild hypermetropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: A form of hypermetropia with not more than +2.00 diopters.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.label: Moderate hypermetropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003172.definition: A form of hypermetropia with more than +2.00 diopters but not more than +5.00 diopters.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Axial myopia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: A form of myopia related to an axial length above the norm and too long for the refractive power of the whole optical system of the eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Increased tear production
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: Increased lacrimation owing to overproduction of tears.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Increased basal tear production
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: A form of watery eye associated with overproduction of tears due to an increased parasympathetic drive to the secretory component of the lacrimal system (lacrimal gland); this could be due to pro-secretory drug use (e.g. pilocarpine) or autonomic disturbance.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Reflex tearing
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: A form of watery eye associated with overproduction of tears due to reflex tearing in response to a local irritant (e.g. trichiasis or foreign body), chronic ocular surface disease (e.g. blepharitis) or systemic disease (e.g. thyroid eye disease).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Lacrimal pump failure
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: A form of watery eye associated with abnormal lid tone and/or lid position. The former is due to lid laxity (common involutional change in the elderly) or a weak orbicularis muscle (e.g. due to VII cranial nerve palsy). The latter is typically associated with ectropion causing punctal eversion.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Involutional entropion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: An abnormal inversion of the eyelid towards the globe resulting from inferior retractor muscle dysfunction with tissue laxity and, possibly, overriding of the preseptal orbicularis muscle over the pretarsal orbicularis muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Cicatricial entropion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: Abnormal inversion (turning inward) of the eyelid towards the globe associated with scarring that vertically shortens the posterior lamella of the eyelid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Mechanical entropion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: A type of entropion (abnormal inversion of the eyelid towards the globe) that is related to a mass effect of a lesion (e.g., a tumor) that pulls the eyelid margin away from the globe.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.label: Abnormal oblique muscle physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003173.definition: A functional anomaly of the inferior or superior oblique muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Abnormal horizontal rectus muscle physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: A functional anomaly of the medial rectus muscle or lateral rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Inferior oblique muscle underaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: Reduced ocular movement by the inferior oblique muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Inferior rectus muscle underaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: Reduced movement by the inferior rectus muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Inferior rectus muscle overaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: Excessive action of the inferior rectus muscle caused by increased innervation typically as a consequence of palsy or limitation to the ipsilateral antagonist or contralateral synergist.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Superior rectus muscle weakness
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: Decreased strength of the superior rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Superior rectus muscle overaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: Excessive action of the superior rectus muscle caused by increased innervation typically as a consequence of palsy or limitation to the ipsilateral antagonist or contralateral synergist.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Superior rectus muscle restriction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the superior rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Superior rectus muscle underaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: Reduced movement of the superior rectus muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Abnormal vertical rectus muscle physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: A functional anomaly of the superior or inferior rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.label: Abnormal lateral rectus muscle physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003174.definition: A functional anomaly of the lateral rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Lateral rectus muscle weakness
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: Decreased strength (ability to move) of the lateral rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Lateral rectus muscle underaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: Reduced movement of the lateral rectus muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Lateral rectus muscle overaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: Excessive action of the lateral rectus muscle caused by increased innervation typically as a consequence of palsy or limitation to the ipsilateral antagonist or contralateral synergist.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Medial rectus muscle weakness
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: Decreased strength of the medial rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Medial rectus muscle overaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: Excessive action of the medial rectus muscle caused by increased innervation typically as a consequence of palsy or limitation to the ipsilateral antagonist or contralateral synergist.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Abnormal rectus muscle physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: A functional anomaly of a vertical or horizontal rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Medial rectus muscle underaction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: Reduced movement of the medial rectus muscle which improves on testing ductions, typically associated with neurogenic palsy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Medial rectus muscle restriction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the medial rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Lateral rectus muscle restriction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: Mechanical limitation of the range of movement of the lateral rectus muscle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.label: Basic constant esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003175.definition: A form of convergent strabismus (esotropia) in which the deviation is present under all conditions (ie at all distances and at all times).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Non-accomodative esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: A form of esotropia in which the angle of deviation is not affected by accommodative effort.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Infantile constant esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: Constant esotropia occurring before 6 months of age. It is typically associated with a large angle of deviation, alternating fixation (therefore low risk of amblyopia) and poor potential for binocular single vision. Other features that might be present in individuals with infantile (constant) esotropia include latent nystagmus or manifest latent nystagmus, dissociated vertical divergence, cyclotropia, abnormal head posture, limited abduction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Distance esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: An intermittent esotropia where binocular single vision is present on near fixation and an esotropia on distance fixation. Often associated with myopia and aging.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Cyclic esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: Convergent strabismus in which normal binocular single vision is alternating with large angle esotropia in rhythmic cycle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Fully accomodative esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: Esotropia in which normal binocular single vision is present for all distances when the hypermetropic refractive error is corrected. Esotropia is present for near and distance on accommodation without correction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Partially accomodative esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: A form of constant esotropia in which the angle of deviation is partially affected by accommodative effort. Typically there is esotropia at near and distance with hypermetropic correction and the angle of deviation increases without glasses.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Convergence excess esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: An intermittent esotropia with binocular single vision present at distance fixation but esotropia on accommodation for near fixation. Usually associated with hypermetropia but patients can be emmetropic and rarely myopic. Associated with a high accommodative convergence/accommodation (AC/A) ratio.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Consecutive esotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: Esotropia in a patient who has previously had exotropia or exophoria; may be constant or intermittent and usually follows surgical overcorrection.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Parafoveal fixation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: Fixation of an object in the area adjacent to the fovea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.label: Peripheral fixation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003176.definition: Fixation of an object in a peripheral area of the retina.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Epicanthus palpebralis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: A type of epicanthus in which a medial vertical fold is present between upper and lower lids.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Epicanthus tarsalis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: A type of epicanthus in which a primarily upper lid fold is present.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Abnormal posterior circulating artery morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: Any structural anomaly of the posterior circulating artery (PCOM).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Posterior communicating artery aneurysm
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: A widening (ballooning) localized in the wall of the posterior communicating artery.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Posterior communicating artery infundibulum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: A funnel-shaped symmetrical enlargement of the origin of the posterior communicating artery at its junction with the internal carotid artery.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Neurogenic strabismus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: An ocular deviation caused by a palsy to one or more of the extraocular muscles or nerves supplying them.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Cyclotropia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: A form of manifest strabismus (heterotropia) in which the one eye is wheel rotated so that the upper end of its vertical axis is nasal (incyclotropia) or temporal (excyclotropia).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Cyclophoria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: A form of latent strabismus (heterophoria) in which the occluded eye wheel-rotates on dissociation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Incyclophoria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: A type of cyclophoria (latent strabismus in which the occluded eye wheel-rotates on dissociation.) in which the upper poles of the globes are rotated inward (medially) to each other.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.label: Excyclophoria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003177.definition: A type of cyclophoria (latent strabismus in which the occluded eye wheel-rotates on dissociation.) in which the upper poles of the globes are rotated outward (laterally) to each other.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Eosinophilic ascites
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: A type of ascites in which there are large numbers of eosinophils in the ascitis fluid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Microtropia with identity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: A type of microtropia with no manifest movement on cover test, the eccentric fixation point coinciding with the angle of ARC.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Microtropia without identity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: A type of microtropia in which the manifest movement is demonstrated on the cover-uncover test.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Absent coronary sinus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: A developmental defect in which the coronary sinus fails to form.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Abnormal ascending aorta morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: Any structural anomaly of the portion of the aorta that arises from the base of the left ventricle and extends upward to the aortic arch and from which the coronary arteries arise.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Abnormal eyelid movement
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: An abnormality in voluntary or involuntary eyelid movements or their control.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Cogan lid twitch
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: Transient eyelid retraction during refixation from down to straight ahead.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Oblique astigmatism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: Astigmatism in which the refractive power of the vertical meridian is the greatest.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: With the rule astigmatism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: Refractive error in which the vertical meridian is relatively hypermetropic and the horizontal meridian is relatively myopic (or ocular astigmatism in which the refractive power of the horizontal meridian is the greatest).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.label: Against the rule astigmatism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003178.definition: Astigmatism with more plus power on the horizontal meridian.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Mixed astigmatism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: A type of astigmatism in which an unequal curvature of the cornea and some cases additionally of the lens causes one meridian of the eye to be hyperopic (farsighted) and a second meridian that is perpendicular to the first to be myopic (nearsighted).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Lenticular astigmatism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: A type of astigmatism related to an irregular shape of the lens.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Irregular astigmatism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: A type of astigmatism in which the principle meridians are not 90 degrees apart and which is associated with loss of vision.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Increased serum leptin
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: An increased concentration of leptin in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Decreased circulating glycerol level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: A decrease below the normal concentration of glycerol in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Abnormal circulating glycerol level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of glycerol in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Recurrent
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: Applies to a sign, symptom or manifestation that occurs multiple times separated by intervals in which the sign, symptom, or manifestation is not present.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Clinical course
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: The course a disease typically takes from its onset, progression in time, and eventual resolution or death of the affected individual.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Elevated circulating apolipoprotein B concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: Increased circulating level of apolipoprotein B, which is the main apolipoprotein of chylomicrons and low density lipoproteins. It occurs in plasma as two main isoforms, apoB-48 and apoB-100.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.label: Decreased circulating apolipoprotein A-I concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003179.definition: Concentration of apolipoprotein A-I below the lower limit of normal. Apolipoprotein A-I is the major protein component of high density lipoprotein (HDL) in plasma. Defects in this gene are associated with HDL deficiencies, including Tangier disease.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.label: Elevated circulating apolipoprotein A-II concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.definition: An increased concentration in blood of apolipoprotein A-II, a major component of HDL particles, associated with triglyceride and glucose metabolism.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.label: Vocal cord dysfunction
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.definition: Any functional anomaly of the vocal cord.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.label: Fundus hemorrhage
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.definition: Bleeding within the fundus of the eye.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.label: Intraretinal hemorrhage
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.definition: A subtype of fundus hemorrhage occurring within the neurosensory retina. Intraretinal haemorrhages may be 'dot' or' blot' shaped or flame shaped depending upon their depth within the retina.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.label: Abnormal basophil count
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.definition: Any deviation from the normal number of basophils per volume in the blood circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.label: Increased basophil count
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.definition: An abnormally increased count of basophils per volume in the blood circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.label: Decreased basophil count
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.definition: An abnormally reduced count of basophils per volume in the blood circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.label: Archibald's sign
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003180.definition: Shortening of the fourth and fifth metacarpals when the fist is clenched.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Anti-ganglioside antibody positivity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: The presence of autoantibodies (immunoglobulins) in the serum that react to gangliosides.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Bilirubinuria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: Presence of conjugated bilirubin in the urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Nitrituria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: Presence of nitrites in the urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Colonic eosinophilia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: An excess of eosinophilic cells in colonic tissue, i.e., eosinophilic infiltration in the colon.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Palilalia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: Repetition of one's own words or phrases is a common occurrence.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Abnormal oral physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: A functional anomaly of the mouth (which is also known as the oral cavity).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Abnormal oral morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: Any structural anomaly of the mouth, which is also known as the oral cavity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Decreased circulating parathyroid hormone level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: An abnormally decreased concentration of parathyroid hormone.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Abnormal waist to hip ratio
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: A deviation from normal of the waist to hip ratio, defined as the waist measurement divided by hip measurement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.label: Increased waist to hip ratio
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003181.definition: Increased waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) is a measurement above the average for the dimensionless ratio of the circumference of the waist to that of the hips. WHR is calculated as waist measurement divided by hip measurement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Decreased waist to hip ratio
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: Decreased waist-to-hip ratio (WHR) is a measurement below the average for the dimensionless ratio of the circumference of the waist to that of the hips. WHR is calculated as waist measurement divided by hip measurement.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Abnormal hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: Altered level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Elevated hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: Abnormally increased level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Reduced hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: Abnormally decreased level of the enzyme that catalyzes conversion of hypoxanthine to inosine monophosphate and guanine to guanosine monophosphate via transfer of the 5-phosphoribosyl group from 5-phosphoribosyl 1-pyrophosphate.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Freezing of gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: Freezing of gait is defined as a brief, episodic absence or marked reduction of forward progression of the feet despite the intention to walk.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Abnormal reflex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: Any anomaly of a reflex, i.e., of an automatic response mediated by the nervous system (a reflex does not need the intervention of conscious thought to occur).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Absent abdominal reflex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: Lack of contraction of abdominal muscles in the quadrant of the abdomen that is stimulated by scraping the skin tangential to or toward the umbilicus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Abnormal superficial reflex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: An anomaly of a reflex that is elicited as a motor response to scraping of the skin. They are generally graded as present or absent. They differ from tendon reflexes in that the sensory signal must ascend the spinal cord to reach the brain and then descend the spinal cord to reach the motor neurons.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.label: Absent cremaster reflex
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003182.definition: Lack of response to scratching of the skin of the medial thigh, which in males normally elicits a brisk, short elevation of the ipsilateral testis, a phenomenon that is referred to as the cremaster reflex.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Pinguecula
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: A pinguecula is a yellowish to brown protruding lesion in the conjunctiva that is easily seen on the nasal and temporal sides of the cornea.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Decreased serum zinc
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: A reduced concentration of zinc in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Hypermetric downward saccades
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: Overshoot of downward saccadic eye movements.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Hypometric upward saccades
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: Saccadic undershoot of upward saccadic eye movements, i.e., an upward saccadic eye movement that has less than the magnitude that would be required to gain fixation of the object.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Aortopulmonary collateral arteries
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: Small ectopic arteries or arterial branches that connect the aorta, aortic branches and/or subclavian artery regions directly to the lung parenchyma, usually seen in conjunction with pulmonary atresia, ventricular septal defect (VSD) and/or closed ductus arteriosus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Abnormal superoxide dismutase level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: An abnormal level of catalysis of the reaction: 2 superoxide + 2 H+ = O2 + hydrogen peroxide.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Increased superoxide dismutase level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: Increased level of catalysis of the reaction: 2 superoxide + 2 H+ = O2 + hydrogen peroxide.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Decreased superoxide dismutase level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: Decreased level of catalysis of the reaction: 2 superoxide + 2 H+ = O2 + hydrogen peroxide.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.label: Presence of xenobiotic
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003183.definition: Presence of a chemical substance found within an individual that is not naturally produced or expected to be present in human tissues or bodily fluids.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Urine xenobiotic
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: The presence of a xenobiotic in urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Positive urine methadone test
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: Detection of methadone or its metabolite 2-ethylidene-1,5-dimethyl-3,3- diphenylpyrrolidine (EDDP) in urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Lymphangiectasis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: Dilation of the lymphatic vessels, the basic process that may result in the formation of a lymphangioma.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Euphoria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: Euphoria is a feeling of intense joy, happiness, excitement, or elation that surpasses what would typically be anticipated in a given situation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Abnormal libido
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: Any deviation from the normal sexual drive or desire for sexual activity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Femur fracture
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: A break or crush injury of the thigh bone (femur).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Difficulty walking backward
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: Reduced ability to walk (ambulate) in a backwards direction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Cock-walk gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: An abnormality of gait that can be observed in individuals with dystonic posture in which the individual walks with an extended trunk and flexed arms, while strutting on the toes without the heels touching the floor.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.label: Sleep-wake inversion
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003184.definition: A reversal of sleeping habits, with a tendency to sleep during the day and be awake at night.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.label: Abnormal hematocrit
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.definition: Any deviation from the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.label: Reduced hematocrit
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.definition: A reduction below the normal ratio of the volume of red blood cells to the total volume of blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.label: Isomerism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.definition: Isomerism in the context of the congenitally malformed heart is defined as a situation where some paired structures on opposite sides of the left-right axis of the body are, in morphologic terms, symmetrical mirror images of each other.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.label: Left Isomerism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.definition: A type of heterotaxy where some paired structures on opposite sides of the left-right axis of the body are symmetrical mirror images of each other, and have the morphology of the normal left-sided structures.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.label: Right isomerism
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.definition: A type of heterotaxy where some paired structures on opposite sides of the left-right axis of the body are symmetrical mirror images of each other, and have the morphology of the normal right-sided structures.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.label: Hobby horse gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.definition: An abnormal gait characterized by toe walking, stiff legs, and skipping. The gait pattern has some resemblance to cock-walk gait, but affected individuals are able to improve their dystonic gait by walking backward.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.label: Ineffective esophageal peristalsis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.definition: Reduced or inadequate esophageal peristalsis, with resultant slow passage of contents through the esophagus.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.label: Esophageal furrows
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003185.definition: Longitudinal grooves in the surface of the esophagus arranged in a longitudinal fashion (from top to bottom of the esophagus).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Abnormal heart rate variability
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Any abnormality in the variability of the time interval between successive heartbeats.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Decreased heart rate variability
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Reduced variation of beat-to-beat intervals of the heart that occurs in conjunction with the respiratory cycle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Increased heart rate variability
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Increased variation of beat-to-beat intervals of the heart that occurs in conjunction with the respiratory cycle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Bloodstream infectious agent
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: The presence of an infectious agent in the blood circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Bacteremia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Presence of viable bacteria in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Abnormal liver physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Any functional anomaly of the liver.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Clasp-knife sign
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Clasp-knife phenomonen refers to increased muscle tone while bending or stretching a limb, whereby there is a sudden relaxation (decrease in resistance) as the muscle continues to be streched. This phenomenon has been likened to opening a clasp knife.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Neck hypertonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Increased passive stiffness or tightness of the neck musculature.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Optic ataxia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Difficulty reaching visually guided goals in peripheral vision, with the deficit, leaves voluntary eye movements largely unaffected.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.label: Recurrent joint dislocation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003186.definition: Dislocation of a given joint repeated times.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Phosphohydroxylysinuria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: An elevated concentration of phosphohydroxylysine in the urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Abnormal Langerhans cell morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: Any functional anomaly of Langerhans cells, which are dendritic cells in the epidermis and some other locations. Langerhans cells play roles in immune surveillance and homeostasis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Absent Birbeck granules in Langerhans cells
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: Birbeck granules (BG) are cytoplasmic organelles that are only found in Langerhans cells (LC). The function of BG is still not completely understood, although most studies point toward an active role in receptor-mediated endocytosis and participation in the antigen-processing/presenting function of LC. This feature refers to the absence of BG in LC, a feature that can be documented by means of electron microscopy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Early chronotype
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: A tendency towards rising very early in the morning and going to bed early in the evening.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Late chronotype
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: A tendency towards waking up very late in the morning and staying up late at night.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Abnormal circulating hepcidin concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of hepcidin in the blood circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Decreased circulating hepcidin concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: Concentration of hepcidin in the blood circulation below the lower limit of normal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Elevated circulating hepcidin concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: Concentration of hepcidin in the blood circulation above the upper limit of normal.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Acromicria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: Small hands and feet in proportion to the rest of the body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.label: Abnormal eyelid physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003187.definition: Any functional abnormality of the eyelid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Eyelid laxity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: Abnormally lax eyelid associated with tissue relaxation; it can be demonstrated by the eyelid distraction test and/or the eyelid snap test.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Decreased tear drainage
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: A form of watery eye associated with obstruction of the nasolacrimal system. This may arise at the level of the punctum, the canaliculi, the sac or the nasolacrimal duct.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Agyria
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: A congenital abnormality of the cerebral hemisphere characterized by lack of gyrations (convolutions) of the cerebral cortex. Agyria is defined as cortical regions lacking gyration with sulci great than 3 cm apart and cerebral cortex thicker than 5 mm.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Increased proinsulin:insulin ratio
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: An elevated concentration of proinsulin (the prohormone precursor to insulin) to mature insulin in the circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Abnormal CSF glucose concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: A deviation from normal concentration of glucose content in the cerebrospinal fluid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Hyperglycorrhachia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: Abnormally high glucose concentration in the cerebrospinal fluid.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Abnormal LDL cholesterol concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Abnormal chylomicron concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: Any deviation from the normal circulating concentration of chylomicrons.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Abnormal HDL cholesterol concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL) in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.label: Abnormal VLDL cholesterol concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003188.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of very-low-density lipoprotein cholesterol in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003189.label: Increased urine urobilinogen
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003189.definition: An elevated concentration of urobilinogen in the urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003189.label: Decreased eosinophil count
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003189.definition: Abnormal reduction in the count of eosinophils in the blood per volume.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003189.label: Rouleaux formation
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003189.definition: Increased amount of stacking of erythrocytes into long chains. Rouleaux (singular: rouleau) is derived from a French word that can refer to a stack of coins put into a cylindircal paper roll. Rouleaux formation is observed with increased serum proteins, particularly fibrinogen and globulins, and represents the cause of increased erythrocte sedimentation rate because rouleaux sediment more readily than isolated red blood cells.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003189.label: Abnormal coagulation factor V activity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003189.definition: Any deviation from the activity of coagulation factor V.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.label: Elevated total serum tryptase
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.definition: An abnormally elevated concentration of total tryptase (alpha and beta tryptase) in the blood circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.label: obsolete Decreased serum mast cell beta-tryptase concentration
Abnormal circulating selenium concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.definition: Any deviation from the normal circulating concentration of selenium.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.label: Abnormal total hemolytic complement activity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.definition: Any deviation from the normal total hemolytic complement activity in the circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.label: Increased total hemolytic complement activity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.definition: An abnormally elevated total hemolytic complement activity in the circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.label: Decreased total hemolytic complement activity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.definition: An abnormally reduced total hemolytic complement activity in the circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.label: Anti-mitochondrial M2 antibody positivity
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.definition: The presence of M2 anti-mitochondrial antibody (immunoglobulins) in the serum.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.label: Micrographia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.definition: Abnormally small-sized handwriting is formally defined as an impairment of fine motor skills, which mainly manifests as a progressive or stable reduction in amplitude during a writing task.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.label: Unicornuate uterus
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003190.definition: A uterus that has a single horn, with a banana-like shape that may or may not have a secondary rudimentary uterine horn.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.label: Abnormal cranial nerve physiology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.definition: A functional abnormality affecting one or more of the cranial nerves, which emerge directly from the brain stem.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.label: Trigeminal anesthesia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.definition: Decreased or absent sensation in the distribution of the trigeminal nerve, which provides tactile, proprioceptive, and nociceptive sensation in the area of the face and mouth.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.label: Rhombencephalosynapsis
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.definition: Rhombencephalosynapsis is a rare brain malformation defined by midline fusion of the cerebellar hemispheres with partial or complete loss of the intervening vermis.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.label: Fluctuating
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.definition: Varying irregularly over time in severity, amount, or amplitude.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.label: Stable
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.definition: This modifier can be applied to a phenotypic feature that does not vary in severity or amount over time.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.label: Digital ulcer
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.definition: An open sore on the surface of the skin of a finger or toe.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.label: Ovarian sex cord-stromal tumor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.definition: A benign or malignant neoplasm that arises from the ovary and is composed of granulosa cells, Sertoli cells, Leydig cells, theca cells, and fibroblasts.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.label: Juvenile type ovarian granulosa cell tumor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003191.definition: Juvenile granulosa cell ovarian tumor (JGCOT) is a rare sex cord stromal tumor, occuring most frequently in premenarchal girls or young women. In contrast to adult granulosa cell tumor, JGCOT has a high mitotic index and more aggressive tumor growth. Microscopically it is seen as diffuse and regularly distributed neoplastic cells with a wide cytoplasm and pleomorphic hyperchromatic nucleus. Follicle formation, in various sizes and shapes, is important in JGCOT. Call-Exner bodies are infrequently seen in JGCOT in contrast to the adult type.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: Malignant ovarian granulosa cell tumor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: An aggressive granulosa cell tumor that arises from the ovary.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: Renal artery duplication
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: The renal arteries carry blood from the aorta to the kidney; normally one renal artery is present on each side of the body. Renal artery duplication refers to the presence of two rather than one renal artery on a given side of the body.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: Hematocolpos
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: Accumulation of blood in the vagina usually due to vaginal obstruction.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: Rope sign
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: The presence of linear erythematous palpable cords, often on the lateral trunk.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: Rosette
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: A halo or spoke-wheel arrangement of cells surrounding a central core or hub. The central hub may consist of an empty-appearing lumen or a space filled with cytoplasmic processes. The cytoplasm of each of the cells in the rosette is often wedge-shaped with the apex directed toward the central core; the nuclei of the cells participating in the rosette are peripherally positioned and form a ring or halo around the hub.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: Homer Wright rosette
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: A type of rosette in which the central lumen or hub is filled with fiber-like processes.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: The tumor cells that form the Flexner-Wintersteiner rosette circumscribe a central lumen that contains small cytoplasmic extensions of the encircling cells; however, unlike the center of the Homer Wright rosette, the central lumen does not contain the fiber-rich neuropil.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: True ependymal rosette
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: A type of rosette in which a halo of cells surrounds an empty lumen.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.label: Perivascular pseudorosette
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003192.definition: A type of rosette in which a spoke-wheel arrangement of cells with tapered cellular processes radiates around a wall of a centrally placed vessel.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.label: Neurocytic rosette
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.definition: A type of rosette that is similar to the Homer Wright rosette, but the central fiber-rich neuropil island is larger and more irregular.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.label: Ocular flutter
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.definition: Ocular flutter is an abnormal eye movement consisting of repetitive, irregular, involuntary bursts of horizontal saccades without an intersaccadic interval. It is generally superimposed on normal oculomotor behaviour and its occurrence may be favoured by various events, such as blinks, the triggering of normal saccades or optokinetic stimulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.label: Aorto-left ventricular tunnel
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.definition: Aorto-left ventricular tunnel (ALVT) is a congenital extracardiac channel connecting the ascending aorta above the sino-tubular junction to either left or right ventricular cavity.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.label: Aorto-right ventricular tunnel
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.definition: The presence of an extracardiac channel that connects the ascending aorta above the sinotubular junction to the cavity of the right ventricle.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.label: Abnormal descending aorta morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.definition: A structural abnormality of the part of the aorta that begins at the aortic arch and then descends through the chest and abdomen.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.label: Ascending aorta hypoplasia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.definition: Significant luminal narrowing of a long segment of or the entire ascending aorta.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.label: Delayed ability to walk
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.definition: A failure to achieve the ability to walk at an appropriate developmental stage. Most children learn to walk in a series of stages, and learn to walk short distances independently between 12 and 15 months.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.label: Abnormal conus terminalis morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003193.definition: Any structural anomaly of the conus terminalis, which is the distal bulbous part of the spinal cord at the location where the spinal cord tapers and ends (usually between the L1 and L2 lumbar vertebrae).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Abnormal portal venous system morphology
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: Any structural anomaly of the portal venous sytem, which comprises all of the veins draining the abdominal part of the digestive tract, including the lower esophagus but excluding the lower anal canal. The portal vein conveys blood from viscera and ramifies like an artery at the liver, ending at the sinusoids. Tributaries of the portal vein, which make up the portal venous system, are the splenic, superior mesenteric, left gastric, right gastric, paraumbilical, and cystic veins.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Congenital absence of portal vein
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: Anomaly where the intestinal and the splenic venous drainage bypass the liver and drain into systemic veins through other possible venous shunts.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Akathisia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: A state of motor restlessness, usually in the lower extremities, that is often but not always accompanied by a subjective sense of inner restlessness, an urge to move, and anxiety or dysphoria.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Pleural thickening
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: An increase in the thickness of the pleura, generally related to scarring of the pleural tissue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Elevated circulating N,N-dimethylglycine concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: An increased concentration of N,N-dimethylglycine in the circulation.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Elevated urinary N,N-dimethylglycine level
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: An increased concentration of N,N-dimethylglycine in the urine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Tongue tremor
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: An unintentional, oscillating to-and-fro muscle movement affecting the tongue.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Snowball lesion of corpus callosum
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: Centrally located corpus callosum hyperintensities said to resemble snowballs upon magnetic resonance imaging (with T2 or Sagittal fluid attenuated inversion recovery [FLAIR] sequences). The central location in the callosum makes them pathognomonic for Susac syndrome.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.label: Recurrent bacterial upper respiratory tract infections
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003194.definition: An increased susceptibility to bacterial upper respiratory tract infections as manifested by a history of recurrent bacterial upper respiratory tract infections (running ears - otitis, sinusitis, pharyngitis, tonsillitis).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Usual interstitial pneumonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: Temporal and spatial heterogeneity in lungs based on presence of fibrosis and honeycombing.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Nocturnal seizures
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: Seizures that occur while the affected individual is sleeping.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Neurogenic claudication
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: Lumbar spinal stenoses may induce symptoms following an individually typical latency on standing or when walking due to swelling of the cauda equina, which leads to compression. This is referred to as neurogenic claudication. The symptoms of lumbar spinal stenosis can be explained by an increase in lumbar lordosis and spinal canal stenosis in an upright position compared to the sitting position or if spondylolisthesis is present by a shift of the vertebrae while standing and walking. Following an individually characteristic distance, walking becomes associated with deep muscular pain and with neurological deficits, such as sensory deficits and paresis in the lower limbs, which resolve within minutes when the affected person sits or lies down. Activities performed in a flexed posture, such as cycling often cause less problems than walking. For the same reason, walking uphill may be tolerated better than walking downhill. Clinical neurological examination at rest may be entirely normal but there is usually pain on hyperextension of the lumbar spine.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Cautious gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: Cautious gait refers to an excessive degree of age-related changes in walking and fear of falling. The walking difficulties seem out of proportion when considering the patient's actual sensory or motor deficits. The gait appears slow, with a wider base than normal, reduced arm swing bilaterally and a slightly stooped posture. This type of gait change often occurs after the first time a patient has fallen.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Dystonic gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: Dystonic gait disorders frequently appear bizarre, particularly because activity increases dystonic tonus and posture. The abnormal posture of the foot in dystonic gait typically involves inversion, plantar flexion and tonic extension of the big toe. In many patients complex types of walking, such as walking backwards and running are paradoxically less impaired than walking forward and may seem completely unaffected. Sensory tricks, for instance, if the affected individual rests a hand on his or her neck, may improve or even normalize dystonic gait in some patients.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Antalgic gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: To avoid pain weight is put on the affected leg for as short a time as possible, resulting in a limp. The patients appear to be walking as if there were a thorn in the sole of the foot. To reduce the load on the affected leg the patients lift and lower their foot in a fixed ankle position.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Elevated circulating aspartate aminotransferase concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: An abnormally high concentration in the circulation of aspartate aminotransferase (AST).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Spastic hemiparetic gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: Spastic hemiparesis is characterized by a dominance of the tonus in the upper limb flexor muscles: the arm is held in an adducted posture and is bent and rotated inwards, the forearm is pronated and the hand and the fingers are flexed. The leg is slightly bent at the hip, the knee cannot be extended fully at the end of the stance phase and the foot is inverted and in a plantar flexed position. Gait is slow, with a wide base and asymmetrical with a shortened weight-bearing phase on the paretic side. During the swing phase, the paretic leg performs a lateral movement (circumduction) which is characteristic of this gait disorder, also termed Wernicke-Mann gait. Spastic gait problems typically worsen on attempts to walk faster.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Spastic paraparetic gait
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: A type of spastic gait in which the legs are usually slightly bent at the hip and in an adducted position. The knees are extended or slightly bent and the feet are in a plantar flexion position. This posture requires circumduction of the legs during walking. The gait may appear stiff (spastic gait disorder) or stiff as well as insecure (spastic ataxic gait disorder). In spastic paraparetic gait, each leg appears to be dragged forward. If the muscle tone in the adductors is marked, the resulting gait disorder is referred to as scissor gait.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.label: Leg dystonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003195.definition: A type of dystonia (abnormally increased muscular tone causing fixed abnormal postures) that affects muscles of the legs.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.label: Arm dystonia
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.definition: A type of dystonia (abnormally increased muscular tone causing fixed abnormal postures) that affects muscles of the arms.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.label: Abnormal serum anion gap
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.definition: Any deviation from the normal value of the serum anion gap, which is calculated from the electrolytes measured in the chemical laboratory, is defined as the sum of serum chloride and bicarbonate concentrations subtracted from the serum sodium concentration.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.label: Elevated serum anion gap
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.definition: An abnormally high value of the serum anion gap (the sum of serum chloride and bicarbonate concentrations subtracted from the serum sodium concentration).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.label: Decreased serum anion gap
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.definition: An abnormally low value of the serum anion gap (the sum of serum chloride and bicarbonate concentrations subtracted from the serum sodium concentration).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.label: Elevated circulating alanine aminotransferase concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.definition: An abnormally high concentration in the circulation of alanine aminotransferase (ALT).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.label: Increased RBC distribution width
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.definition: Red blood cell distribution width (RDW) is a simple parameter of the standard full blood count and a measure of heterogeneity in the size of circulating erythrocytes. It is provided by automated hematology analyzers and it reflects the range of the red cell size. It is calculated by dividing the standard deviation of erythrocyte volume by the mean corpuscular volume (MCV) and multiplied by 100 to convert to a percentage.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.label: Cloudy urine
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.definition: The appearance of the urine having visible material in suspension, i.e., appearing cloudy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.label: Reduced blood urea nitrogen
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003196.definition: An abnormally low concentration of urea nitrogen in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.label: Abnormal blood urea nitrogen concentration
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.definition: Any deviation from the normal concentration of urea nitrogen in the blood.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.label: Subaortic ventricular septal bulge
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.definition: A localized hypertrophy of the subaortic segment of the ventricular septum has been frequently described in elderly persons, and variously termed subaortic ventricular septal bulge (VSB), sigmoid-shaped septum, localized or discrete upper septal hypertrophy.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.label: Presyncope
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.definition: Presyncope is a state of lightheadedness, muscular weakness, blurred vision, and feeling faint. Presyncope is most often cardiovascular in cause.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.label: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.definition: An abnormal increase in the ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc.

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.label: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 0.6
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.definition: Ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc is 0.6 (The normal cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.label: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 0.7
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.definition: Ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc is 0.7 (The normal cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.label: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 0.8
http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.definition: Ratio of the height of the cup of the optic nerve head to the height of the disc is 0.8 (The normal cup-to-disc ratio is 0.3).

http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/HP_003197.label: Increased vertical cup-to-disc ratio - 0.9
